verses.textEn: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and God was the Word.
verses.textLa: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.
verses.notes: The words 'Deus' and 'Verbum' are both in the nominative case, so the text could be read as 'God was the Word,' or as 'the Word was God.' However, word order in Latin is not entirely irrelevant, therefore this translation prefers ‘God was the Word,’ over ‘the Word was God.’ The same translation choice is made in the original Rheims New Testament of 1582.

verses.textEn: He was with God in the beginning.
verses.textLa: Hoc erat in principio apud Deum.

verses.textEn: All things were made through Him, and nothing that was made was made without Him.
verses.textLa: Omnia per ipsum facta sunt: et sine ipso factum est nihil, quod factum est,

verses.textEn: Life was in Him, and Life was the light of men.
verses.textLa: in ipso vita erat, et vita erat lux hominum:
verses.notes: Deus, Verbum, Vita represents Father, Son, Spirit.

verses.textEn: And the light shines in the darkness, and the darkness did not comprehend it.
verses.textLa: et lux in tenebris lucet, et tenebræ eam non comprehenderunt.
verses.notes: The darkness represents the fallen angels and all evil in the world, which cannot understand the light of goodness. Notice that the light shines in the present tense, which is the closest tense to the timelessness of the Eternity of God, but the darkness is spoken of using the past tense, because fallen angels are trapped in Time.

verses.textEn: There was a man sent by God, whose name was John.
verses.textLa: Fuit homo missus a Deo, cui nomen erat Ioannes.

verses.textEn: He arrived as a witness to offer testimony about the Light, so that all would believe through him.
verses.textLa: Hic venit in testimonium ut testimonium perhiberet de lumine, ut omnes crederent per illum.

verses.textEn: He was not the Light, but he was to offer testimony about the Light.
verses.textLa: Non erat ille lux, sed ut testimonium perhiberet de lumine.

verses.textEn: The true Light, which illuminates every man, was coming into this world.
verses.textLa: Erat lux vera, quæ illuminat omnem hominem venientem in hunc mundum.

verses.textEn: He was in the world, and the world was made through him, and the world did not recognize him.
verses.textLa: In mundo erat, et mundus per ipsum factus est, et mundus eum non cognovit.

verses.textEn: He went to his own, and his own did not accept him.
verses.textLa: In propria venit, et sui eum non receperunt.

verses.textEn: Yet whoever did accept him, those who believed in his name, he gave them the power to become the sons of God.
verses.textLa: Quotquot autem receperunt eum, dedit eis potestatem filios Dei fieri, his qui credunt in nomine eius:

verses.textEn: These are born, not of blood, nor of the will of flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God.
verses.textLa: qui non ex sanguinibus, neque ex voluntate carnis, neque ex voluntate viri, sed ex Deo nati sunt.

verses.textEn: And the Word became flesh, and he lived among us, and we saw his glory, glory like that of an only-begotten Son from the Father, full of grace and truth.
verses.textLa: Et verbum caro factum est, et habitavit in nobis: et vidimus gloriam eius, gloriam quasi unigeniti a Patre plenum gratiæ et veritatis.

verses.textEn: John offers testimony about him, and he cries out, saying: “This is the one about whom I said: ‘He who is to come after me, has been placed ahead of me, because he existed before me.’ ”
verses.textLa: Ioannes testimonium perhibet de ipso, et clamat dicens: Hic erat, quem dixi: Qui post me venturus est, ante me factus est: quia prior me erat.
verses.notes: On one level of meaning, ‘ante me factus est’ means ‘ranks ahead of me.’ But there are other levels of meaning which that translation obscures. This is a frequent translation dilemma: one translation makes one level of meaning clearer, and other levels of meaning more obscure.

verses.textEn: And from his fullness, we all have received, even grace for grace.
verses.textLa: Et de plenitudine eius nos omnes accepimus, et gratiam pro gratia.
verses.notes: This verse (particularly the last phrase) has several levels of meaning, and is somewhat obscure. This translation does not try to clear up every obscurity in Scripture, nor does it try to decide between various levels of meaning. On one level, it means that we have received grace upon grace; on another level, it means that we need grace from Christ for everything we do, even our cooperation with grace is a grace. And it seems to me that there are other levels of meaning also.

verses.textEn: For the law was given through Moses, but grace and truth came through Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: quia lex per Moysen data est; gratia, et veritas per Iesum Christum facta est.

verses.textEn: No one ever saw God; the only-begotten Son, who is in the bosom of the Father, he himself has described him.
verses.textLa: Deum nemo vidit umquam: unigenitus Filius, qui est in sinu Patris, ipse enarravit.

verses.textEn: And this is the testimony of John, when the Jews sent priests and Levites from Jerusalem to him, so that they might ask him, “Who are you?”
verses.textLa: Et hoc est testimonium Ioannis, quando miserunt Iudæi ab Ierosolymis sacerdotes et Levitas ad eum ut interrogarent eum: Tu quis es?

verses.textEn: And he confessed it and did not deny it; and what he confessed was: “I am not the Christ.”
verses.textLa: Et confessus est, et non negavit: et confessus est: Quia non sum ego Christus.

verses.textEn: And they questioned him: “Then what are you? Are you Elijah?” And he said, “I am not.” “Are you the Prophet?” And he answered, “No.”
verses.textLa: Et interrogaverunt eum: Quid ergo? Elias es tu? Et dixit: Non sum. Propheta es tu? Et respondit: Non.

verses.textEn: Therefore, they said to him: “Who are you, so that we may give an answer to those who sent us? What do you say about yourself?”
verses.textLa: Dixerunt ergo ei: Quis es ut responsum demus his, qui miserunt nos? Quid dicis de teipso?

verses.textEn: He said, “I am a voice crying out in the desert, ‘Make straight the way of the Lord,’ just as the prophet Isaiah said.”
verses.textLa: Ait: Ego vox clamantis in deserto: Dirigite viam Domini, sicut dixit Isaias propheta.

verses.textEn: And some of those who had been sent were from among the Pharisees.
verses.textLa: Et qui missi fuerant, erant ex Pharisæis.

verses.textEn: And they questioned him and said to him, “Then why do you baptize, if you are not the Christ, and not Elijah, and not the Prophet?”
verses.textLa: Et interrogaverunt eum, et dixerunt ei: Quid ergo baptizas, si tu non es Christus, neque Elias, neque Propheta?

verses.textEn: John answered them by saying: “I baptize with water. But in your midst stands one, whom you do not know.
verses.textLa: Respondit eis Ioannes, dicens: Ego baptizo in aqua: medius autem vestrum stetit, quem vos nescitis.

verses.textEn: The same is he who is to come after me, who has been placed ahead of me, the laces of whose shoes I am not worthy to loosen.”
verses.textLa: Ipse est, qui post me venturus est, qui ante me factus est: cuius ego non sum dignus ut solvam eius corrigiam calceamenti.

verses.textEn: These things happened in Bethania, across the Jordan, where John was baptizing.
verses.textLa: Hæc in Bethania facta sunt trans Iordanem, ubi erat Ioannes baptizans.

verses.textEn: On the next day, John saw Jesus coming toward him, and so he said: “Behold, the Lamb of God. Behold, he who takes away the sin of the world.
verses.textLa: Altera die vidit Ioannes Iesum venientem ad se, et ait: Ecce agnus Dei. Ecce qui tollit peccatum mundi.

verses.textEn: This is the one about whom I said, ‘After me arrives a man, who has been placed ahead of me, because he existed before me.’
verses.textLa: Hic est, de quo dixi: Post me venit vir, qui ante me factus est: quia prior me erat.

verses.textEn: And I did not know him. Yet it is for this reason that I come baptizing with water: so that he may be made manifest in Israel.”
verses.textLa: et ego nesciebam eum, sed ut manifestetur in Israel, propterea veni ego in aqua baptizans.

verses.textEn: And John offered testimony, saying: “For I saw the Spirit descending from heaven like a dove; and he remained upon him.
verses.textLa: Et testimonium perhibuit Ioannes, dicens: Quia vidi Spiritum descendentem quasi columbam de cælo, et mansit super eum.

verses.textEn: And I did not know him. But he who sent me to baptize with water said to me: ‘He over whom you will see the Spirit descending and remaining upon him, this is the one who baptizes with the Holy Spirit.’
verses.textLa: Et ego nesciebam eum: sed qui misit me baptizare in aqua, ille mihi dixit: Super quem videris Spiritum descendentem, et manentem super eum, hic est, qui baptizat in Spiritu Sancto.

verses.textEn: And I saw, and I gave testimony: that this one is the Son of God.”
verses.textLa: Et ego vidi: et testimonium perhibui quia hic est Filius Dei.

verses.textEn: The next day again, John was standing with two of his disciples.
verses.textLa: Altera die iterum stabat Ioannes, et ex discipulis eius duo.

verses.textEn: And catching sight of Jesus walking, he said, “Behold, the Lamb of God.”
verses.textLa: Et respiciens Iesum ambulantem, dicit: Ecce agnus Dei.

verses.textEn: And two disciples were listening to him speaking. And they followed Jesus.
verses.textLa: Et audierunt eum duo discipuli loquentem, et secuti sunt Iesum.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus, turning around and seeing them following him, said to them, “What are you seeking?” And they said to him, “Rabbi (which means in translation, Teacher), where do you live?”
verses.textLa: Conversus autem Iesus, et videns eos sequentes se, dicit eis: Quid quæritis? Qui dixerunt ei: Rabbi, (quod dicitur interpretatum Magister) ubi habitas?

verses.textEn: He said to them, “Come and see.” They went and saw where he was staying, and they stayed with him that day. Now it was about the tenth hour.
verses.textLa: Dicit eis: Venite, et videte. Venerunt, et viderunt ubi maneret, et apud eum manserunt die illo: hora autem erat quasi decima.

verses.textEn: And Andrew, the brother of Simon Peter, was one of the two who had heard about him from John and had followed him.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Andreas frater Simonis Petri unus ex duobus, qui audierant a Ioanne, et secuti fuerant eum.

verses.textEn: First, he found his brother Simon, and he said to him, “We have found the Messiah,” (which is translated as the Christ).
verses.textLa: Invenit hic primum fratrem suum Simonem, et dicit ei: Invenimus Messiam (quod est interpretatum Christus).

verses.textEn: And he led him to Jesus. And Jesus, gazing at him, said: “You are Simon, son of Jonah. You shall be called Cephas,” (which is translated as Peter).
verses.textLa: Et adduxit eum ad Iesum. Intuitus autem eum Iesus, dixit: Tu es Simon filius Iona: tu vocaberis Cephas, (quod interpretatur Petrus).
verses.notes: I believe that John originally wrote his Gospel in Aramaic, the same language that Jesus most often used to teach, and that later John’s disciples translated it into Greek and added to it. That is why there are repeated references in the text saying ‘which is translated as.’

verses.textEn: On the next day, he wanted to go into Galilee, and he found Philip. And Jesus said to him, “Follow me.”
verses.textLa: In crastinum voluit exire in Galilæam, et invenit Philippum. Et dicit ei Iesus: Sequere me.

verses.textEn: Now Philip was from Bethsaida, the city of Andrew and Peter.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Philippus a Bethsaida, civitate Andreæ, et Petri.

verses.textEn: Philip found Nathanael, and he said to him, “We have found the one about whom Moses wrote in the Law and the Prophets: Jesus, the son of Joseph, from Nazareth.”
verses.textLa: Invenit Philippus Nathanael, et dicit ei: Quem scripsit Moyses in Lege, et Prophetæ, invenimus Iesum filium Ioseph a Nazareth.

verses.textEn: And Nathanael said to him, “Can anything good be from Nazareth?” Philip said to him, “Come and see.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit ei Nathanael: A Nazareth potest aliquid boni esse? Dicit ei Philippus: Veni, et vide.

verses.textEn: Jesus saw Nathanael coming toward him, and he said about him, “Behold, an Israelite in whom truly there is no deceit.”
verses.textLa: Vidit Iesus Nathanael venientem ad se, et dicit de eo: Ecce vere Israelita, in quo dolus non est.

verses.textEn: Nathanael said to him, “From where do you know me?” Jesus responded and said to him, “Before Philip called you, when you were under the fig tree, I saw you.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Nathanael: Unde me nosti? Respondit Iesus, et dixit ei: Priusquam te Philippus vocavit, cum esses sub ficu, vidi te.

verses.textEn: Nathanael answered him and said: “Rabbi, you are the Son of God. You are the King of Israel.”
verses.textLa: Respondit ei Nathanael, et ait: Rabbi, tu es Filius Dei, tu es Rex Israel.
verses.notes: He was able to perceive the truth so readily because there was no deceit in him.

verses.textEn: Jesus responded and said to him: “Because I told you that I saw you under the fig tree, you believe. Greater things than these, you will see.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus, et dixit ei: Quia dixi tibi: Vidi te sub ficu, credis: maius his videbis.

verses.textEn: And he said to him, “Amen, amen, I say to you, you will see heaven opened, and the Angels of God ascending and descending over the Son of man.”
verses.textLa: Et dicit ei: Amen, amen dico vobis, videbitis cælum apertum, et Angelos Dei ascendentes, et descendentes supra Filium hominis.

verses.textEn: And on the third day, a wedding was held in Cana of Galilee, and the mother of Jesus was there.
verses.textLa: Et die tertia nuptiæ factæ sunt in Cana Galilææ, et erat mater Iesu ibi.

verses.textEn: Now Jesus was also invited to the wedding, with his disciples.
verses.textLa: Vocatus est autem et Iesus, et discipuli eius ad nuptias.

verses.textEn: And when the wine was failing, the mother of Jesus said to him, “They have no wine.”
verses.textLa: Et deficiente vino, dicit mater Iesu ad eum: Vinum non habent.
verses.notes: Mary is saying that they lack the wine of a true Sacrament of marriage, for all they have is the water of an Old Testament (natural) marriage.

verses.textEn: And Jesus said to her: “What is that to me and to you, woman? My hour has not yet arrived.”
verses.textLa: Et dicit ei Iesus: Quid mihi, et tibi est, mulier? Nondum venit hora mea.
verses.notes: Jesus replies that He has not yet died on the Cross, which is the source of all the Sacraments. But she knows that time is no obstacle to God.

verses.textEn: His mother said to the servants, “Do whatever he tells you.”
verses.textLa: Dicit mater eius ministris: Quodcumque dixerit vobis, facite.

verses.textEn: Now in that place, there were six stone water jars, for the purification ritual of the Jews, containing two or three measures each.
verses.textLa: Erant autem ibi lapideæ hydriæ sex positæ secundum purificationem Iudæorum, capientes singulæ metretas binas vel ternas.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to them, “Fill the water jars with water.” And they filled them to the very top.
verses.textLa: Dicit eis Iesus: Implete hydrias aqua. Et impleverunt eas usque ad summum.

verses.textEn: And Jesus said to them, “Now draw from it, and carry it to the chief steward of the feast.” And they took it to him.
verses.textLa: Et dicit eis Iesus: Haurite nunc, et ferte architriclinio. Et tulerunt.

verses.textEn: Then, when the chief steward had tasted the water made into wine, since he did not know where it was from, for only the servants who had drawn the water knew, the chief steward called the groom,
verses.textLa: Ut autem gustavit architriclinius aquam vinum factam, et non sciebat unde esset, ministri autem sciebant, qui hauserant aquam: vocat sponsum architriclinius,

verses.textEn: and he said to him: “Every man offers the good wine first, and then, when they have become inebriated, he offers what is worse. But you have kept the good wine until now.”
verses.textLa: et dicit ei: Omnis homo primum bonum vinum ponit: et cum inebriati fuerint, tunc id, quod deterius est. Tu autem servasti bonum vinum usque adhuc.
verses.notes: Jesus turned the water of the Old Testament marriage into the wine of the New Testament marriage.

verses.textEn: This was the beginning of the signs that Jesus accomplished in Cana of Galilee, and it manifested his glory, and his disciples believed in him.
verses.textLa: Hoc fecit initium signorum Iesus in Cana Galilææ: et manifestavit gloriam suam, et crediderunt in eum discipuli eius.

verses.textEn: After this, he descended to Capernaum, with his mother and his brothers and his disciples, but they did not remain there for many days.
verses.textLa: Post hoc descendit Capharnaum ipse, et mater eius, et fratres eius, et discipuli eius: et ibi manserunt non multis diebus.

verses.textEn: And the Passover of the Jews was near, and so Jesus ascended to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et prope erat Pascha Iudæorum, et ascendit Iesus Ierosolymam:

verses.textEn: And he found, sitting in the temple, sellers of oxen and sheep and doves, and the moneychangers.
verses.textLa: et invenit in templo vendentes boves, et oves, et columbas, et numularios sedentes.

verses.textEn: And when he had made something like a whip out of little cords, he drove them all out of the temple, including the sheep and the oxen. And he poured out the brass coins of the moneychangers, and he overturned their tables.
verses.textLa: Et cum fecisset quasi flagellum de funiculis, omnes eiecit de templo, oves quoque, et boves, et numulariorum effudit æs, et mensas subvertit.

verses.textEn: And to those who were selling doves, he said: “Take these things out of here, and do not make my Father’s house into a house of commerce.”
verses.textLa: Et his, qui columbas vendebant, dixit: Auferte ista hinc, et nolite facere domum Patris mei, domum negotiationis.

verses.textEn: And truly, his disciples were reminded that it is written: “Zeal for your house consumes me.”
verses.textLa: Recordati sunt vero discipuli eius quia scriptum est: Zelus domus tuæ comedit me.

verses.textEn: Then the Jews responded and said to him, “What sign can you show to us, that you may do these things?”
verses.textLa: Responderunt ergo Iudæi, et dixerunt ei: Quod signum ostendis nobis quia hæc facis?

verses.textEn: Jesus responded and said to them, “Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus, et dixit eis: Solvite templum hoc, et in tribus diebus excitabo illud.
verses.notes: The word ‘Solvite’ is not so much ‘destroy’ as it is to loosen or release or set free. Jesus is referring primarily to his own death, which is not his destruction, but the separation of his soul from his body, a kind of loosening or release.

verses.textEn: Then the Jews said, “This temple has been built up over forty-six years, and you will raise it up in three days?”
verses.textLa: Dixerunt ergo Iudæi: Quadraginta et sex annis ædificatum est templum hoc, et tu in tribus diebus excitabis illud?
verses.notes:
The length of time, 46 years, is divided into 40 plus 6 providentially. The 46 years is counted as the 46th Passover since the completion of the rebuilding of the Temple Sanctuary, which took 1.5 years. Josephus tell us that the Temple more generally, not merely the Sanctuary alone, took 8 years. Subtracting 1.5 years gives us 6.5 years: the length of time from the completion of the Sanctuary (at which time the rebuilt Temple was consecrated to God and the count of the years began) to the completion of the other buildings related to the Sanctuary. Then 40 more years are counted until Christ cleansed the temple by driving out the buyers and sellers.
 Since Jesus was referring to his body as a temple, of which the temple building is merely a symbol, this passage also refers symbolically to the length of time since the Immaculate Conception. This was now the 46th Passover since the Immaculate Conception, when God began to build the temple of Christ’s body by first building the temple of Mary’s body, in which God dwelt for 9 months (in the womb).

verses.textEn: Yet he was speaking about the Temple of his body.
verses.textLa: Ille autem dicebat de Templo corporis sui.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when he had resurrected from the dead, his disciples were reminded that he had said this, and they believed in the Scriptures and in the word that Jesus had spoken.
verses.textLa: Cum ergo resurrexisset a mortuis, recordati sunt discipuli eius, quia hoc dicebat, et crediderunt Scripturæ, et sermoni, quem dixit Iesus.

verses.textEn: Now while he was at Jerusalem during the Passover, on the day of the feast, many trusted in his name, seeing his signs that he was accomplishing.
verses.textLa: Cum autem esset Ierosolymis in Pascha in die festo, multi crediderunt in nomine eius, videntes signa eius, quæ faciebat.

verses.textEn: But Jesus did not trust himself to them, because he himself had knowledge of all persons,
verses.textLa: Ipse autem Iesus non credebat semetipsum eis, eo quod ipse nosset omnes,

verses.textEn: and because he had no need of anyone to offer testimony about a man. For he knew what was within a man.
verses.textLa: et quia opus ei non erat ut quis testimonium perhiberet de homine: ipse enim sciebat quid esset in homine.

verses.textEn: Now there was a man among the Pharisees, named Nicodemus, a leader of the Jews.
verses.textLa: Erat autem homo ex Pharisæis, Nicodemus nomine, princeps Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: He went to Jesus at night, and he said to him: “Rabbi, we know that you have arrived as a teacher from God. For no one would be able to accomplish these signs, which you accomplish, unless God were with him.”
verses.textLa: Hic venit ad Iesum nocte, et dixit ei: Rabbi, scimus quia a Deo venisti magister, nemo enim potest hæc signa facere, quæ tu facis, nisi fuerit Deus cum eo.

verses.textEn: Jesus responded and said to him, “Amen, amen, I say to you, unless one has been reborn anew, he is not able to see the kingdom of God.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus, et dixit ei: Amen, amen dico tibi, nisi quis renatus fuerit denuo, non potest videre regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: Nicodemus said to him: “How could a man be born when he is old? Surely, he cannot enter a second time into his mother’s womb to be reborn?”
verses.textLa: Dicit ad eum Nicodemus: Quomodo potest homo nasci, cum sit senex? Numquid potest in ventrem matris suæ iterato introire, et renasci?

verses.textEn: Jesus responded: “Amen, amen, I say to you, unless one has been reborn by water and the Holy Spirit, he is not able to enter into the kingdom of God.
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus: Amen, amen dico tibi, nisi quis renatus fuerit ex aqua, et Spiritu Sancto, non potest introire in regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: What is born of the flesh is flesh, and what is born of the Spirit is spirit.
verses.textLa: Quod natum est ex carne, caro est: et quod natum est ex Spiritu, spiritus est.

verses.textEn: You should not be amazed that I said to you: You must be born anew.
verses.textLa: Non mireris quia dixi tibi: oportet vos nasci denuo.

verses.textEn: The Spirit inspires where he wills. And you hear his voice, but you do not know where he comes from, or where he is going. So it is with all who are born of the Spirit.”
verses.textLa: Spiritus ubi vult spirat: et vocem eius audis, sed nescis unde veniat, aut quo vadat: sic est omnis, qui natus est ex spiritu.
verses.notes: I realize that this verse is translated using a dangling preposition, but it sounds more natural in conversation to leave it this way, whereas the grammatically correct alternative is awkward.

verses.textEn: Nicodemus responded and said to him, “How are these things able to be accomplished?”
verses.textLa: Respondit Nicodemus, et dixit ei: Quomodo possunt hæc fieri?

verses.textEn: Jesus responded and said to him: “You are a teacher in Israel, and you are ignorant of these things?
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus, et dixit ei: Tu es magister in Israel, et hæc ignoras?

verses.textEn: Amen, amen, I say to you, that we speak about what we know, and we testify about what we have seen. But you do not accept our testimony.
verses.textLa: Amen, amen dico tibi, quia quod scimus loquimur, et quod vidimus testamur, et testimonium nostrum non accipitis.
verses.notes: Jesus uses the first person plural here because He is referring to the work done by Himself and the Holy Spirit together.

verses.textEn: If I have spoken to you about earthly things, and you have not believed, then how will you believe, if I will speak to you about heavenly things?
verses.textLa: Si terrena dixi vobis, et non creditis: quomodo, si dixero vobis cælestia, credetis?

verses.textEn: And no one has ascended to heaven, except the one who descended from heaven: the Son of man who is in heaven.
verses.textLa: Et nemo ascendit in cælum, nisi qui descendit de cælo, Filius hominis, qui est in cælo.

verses.textEn: And just as Moses lifted up the serpent in the desert, so also must the Son of man be lifted up,
verses.textLa: Et sicut Moyses exaltavit serpentem in deserto; ita exaltari oportet Filium hominis:

verses.textEn: so that whoever believes in him may not perish, but may have eternal life.
verses.textLa: ut omnis, qui credit in ipsum, non pereat, sed habeat vitam æternam.

verses.textEn: For God so loved the world that he gave his only-begotten Son, so that all who believe in him may not perish, but may have eternal life.
verses.textLa: Sic enim Deus dilexit mundum, ut Filium suum unigenitum daret: ut omnis, qui credit in eum, non pereat, sed habeat vitam æternam.

verses.textEn: For God did not send his Son into the world, in order to judge the world, but in order that the world may be saved through him.
verses.textLa: Non enim misit Deus Filium suum in mundum, ut iudicet mundum, sed ut salvetur mundus per ipsum.

verses.textEn: Whoever believes in him is not judged. But whoever does not believe is already judged, because he does not believe in the name of the only-begotten Son of God.
verses.textLa: Qui credit in eum, non iudicatur: qui autem non credit, iam iudicatus est: quia non credit in nomine unigeniti Filii Dei.

verses.textEn: And this is the judgment: that the Light has come into the world, and men loved darkness more than light. For their works were evil.
verses.textLa: Hoc est autem iudicium: quia lux venit in mundum, et dilexerunt homines magis tenebras, quam lucem: erant enim eorum mala opera.

verses.textEn: For everyone who does evil hates the Light and does not go toward the Light, so that his works may not be corrected.
verses.textLa: Omnis enim, qui male agit, odit lucem, et non venit ad lucem, ut non arguantur opera eius:

verses.textEn: But whoever acts in truth goes toward the Light, so that his works may be manifested, because they have been accomplished in God.”
verses.textLa: qui autem facit veritatem, venit ad lucem, ut manifestentur opera eius, quia in Deo sunt facta.

verses.textEn: After these things, Jesus and his disciples went into the land of Judea. And he was living there with them and baptizing.
verses.textLa: Post hæc venit Iesus, et discipuli eius in terram Iudæam: et illic demorabatur cum eis, et baptizabat.

verses.textEn: Now John was also baptizing, at Aenon near Salim, because there was much water in that place. And they were arriving and being baptized.
verses.textLa: Erat autem et Ioannes baptizans in Ænnon, iuxta Salim: quia aquæ multæ erant illic, et veniebant, et baptizabantur.

verses.textEn: For John had not yet been cast into prison.
verses.textLa: Nondum enim missus fuerat Ioannes in carcerem.

verses.textEn: Then a dispute occurred between the disciples of John and the Jews, about purification.
verses.textLa: Facta est autem quæstio ex discipulis Ioannis cum Iudæis de Purificatione.

verses.textEn: And they went to John and said to him: “Rabbi, the one who was with you across the Jordan, about whom you offered testimony: behold, he is baptizing and everyone is going to him.”
verses.textLa: Et venerunt ad Ioannem, et dixerunt ei: Rabbi, qui erat tecum trans Iordanem, cui tu testimonium perhibuisti, ecce hic baptizat, et omnes veniunt ad eum.

verses.textEn: John responded and said: “A man is not able to receive anything, unless it has been given to him from heaven.
verses.textLa: Respondit Ioannes, et dixit: Non potest homo accipere quidquam, nisi fuerit ei datum de cælo.

verses.textEn: You yourselves offer testimony for me that I said, ‘I am not the Christ,’ but that I have been sent before him.
verses.textLa: Ipsi vos mihi testimonium perhibetis, quod dixerim: Non sum ego Christus: sed quia missus sum ante illum.

verses.textEn: He who holds the bride is the groom. But the friend of the groom, who stands and listens to Him, rejoices joyfully at the voice of the groom. And so, this, my joy, has been fulfilled.
verses.textLa: Qui habet sponsam, sponsus est: amicus autem sponsi, qui stat, et audit eum, gaudio gaudet propter vocem sponsi. Hoc ergo gaudium meum impletum est.

verses.textEn: He must increase, while I must decrease.
verses.textLa: Illum oportet crescere, me autem minui.

verses.textEn: He who comes from above, is above everything. He who is from below, is of the earth, and he speaks about the earth. He who comes from heaven is above everything.
verses.textLa: Qui desursum venit, super omnes est. Qui est de terra, de terra est, et de terra loquitur. Qui de cælo venit, super omnes est.

verses.textEn: And what he has seen and heard, about this he testifies. And no one accepts his testimony.
verses.textLa: Et quod vidit, et audivit, hoc testatur: et testimonium eius nemo accipit.

verses.textEn: Whoever has accepted his testimony has certified that God is truthful.
verses.textLa: Qui accepit eius testimonium, signavit quia Deus verax est.

verses.textEn: For he whom God has sent speaks the words of God. For God does not give the Spirit by measure.
verses.textLa: Quem enim misit Deus, verba Dei loquitur: non enim ad mensuram dat Deus Spiritum.

verses.textEn: The Father loves the Son, and he has given everything into his hand.
verses.textLa: Pater diligit Filium: et omnia dedit in manu eius.

verses.textEn: Whoever believes in the Son has eternal life. But whoever is unbelieving toward the Son shall not see life; instead the wrath of God remains upon him.”
verses.textLa: Qui credit in Filium, habet vitam æternam: qui autem incredulus est Filio, non videbit vitam, sed ira Dei manet super eum.

verses.textEn: And so, when Jesus realized that the Pharisees had heard that Jesus made more disciples and baptized more than John,
verses.textLa: Ut ergo cognovit Iesus quia audierunt Pharisæi quod Iesus plures discipulos facit, et baptizat, quam Ioannes,

verses.textEn: (though Jesus himself was not baptizing, but only his disciples)
verses.textLa: (quamquam Iesus non baptizaret, sed discipuli eius)

verses.textEn: he left behind Judea, and he traveled again to Galilee.
verses.textLa: reliquit Iudæam, et abiit iterum in Galilæam.

verses.textEn: Now he needed to cross through Samaria.
verses.textLa: Oportebat autem eum transire per Samariam.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he went into a city of Samaria which is called Sychar, near the estate which Jacob gave to his son Joseph.
verses.textLa: Venit ergo in civitatem Samariæ, quæ dicitur Sichar: iuxta prædium, quod dedit Iacob Ioseph filio suo.

verses.textEn: And Jacob’s well was there. And so Jesus, being tired from the journey, was sitting in a certain way on the well. It was about the sixth hour.
verses.textLa: Erat autem ibi fons Iacob. Iesus ergo fatigatus ex itinere, sedebat sic supra fontem. Hora erat quasi sexta.

verses.textEn: A woman of Samaria arrived to draw water. Jesus said to her, “Give me to drink.”
verses.textLa: Venit mulier de Samaria haurire aquam. Dicit ei Iesus: Da mihi bibere.

verses.textEn: For his disciples had gone into the city in order to buy food.
verses.textLa: (Discipuli enim eius abierant in civitatem ut cibos emerent.)

verses.textEn: And so, that Samaritan woman said to him, “How is it that you, being a Jew, are requesting a drink from me, though I am a Samaritan woman?” For the Jews do not associate with the Samaritans.
verses.textLa: Dicit ergo ei mulier illa Samaritana: Quomodo tu Iudæus cum sis, bibere a me poscis, quæ sum mulier Samaritana? Non enim coutuntur Iudæi Samaritanis.

verses.textEn: Jesus responded and said to her: “If you knew the gift of God, and who it is who is saying to you, ‘Give me to drink,’ perhaps you would have made a request of him, and he would have given you living water.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus, et dixit ei: Si scires donum Dei, et quis est, qui dicit tibi: Da mihi bibere: tu forsitan petisses ab eo, et dedisset tibi aquam vivam.

verses.textEn: The woman said to him: “Lord, you do not have anything with which to draw water, and the well is deep. From where, then, do you have living water?
verses.textLa: Dicit ei mulier: Domine, neque in quo haurias habes, et puteus altus est: unde ergo habes aquam vivam?

verses.textEn: Surely, you are not greater than our father Jacob, who gave us the well and who drank from it, with his sons and his cattle?”
verses.textLa: Numquid tu maior es patre nostro Iacob, qui dedit nobis puteum, et ipse ex eo bibit, et filii eius, et pecora eius?

verses.textEn: Jesus responded and said to her: “All who drink from this water will thirst again. But whoever shall drink from the water that I will give to him will not thirst for eternity.
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus, et dixit ei: Omnis, qui bibit ex aqua hac, sitiet iterum: qui autem biberit ex aqua, quam ego dabo ei, non sitiet in æternum:

verses.textEn: Instead, the water that I will give to him will become in him a fountain of water, springing up into eternal life.”
verses.textLa: sed aqua, quam ego dabo ei, fiet in eo fons aquæ salientis in vitam æternam.

verses.textEn: The woman said to him, “Lord, give me this water, so that I may not thirst and may not come here to draw water.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ad eum mulier: Domine, da mihi hanc aquam, ut non sitiam: neque veniam huc haurire.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to her, “Go, call your husband, and return here.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Iesus: Vade, voca virum tuum, et veni huc.

verses.textEn: The woman responded and said, “I have no husband.” Jesus said to her: “You have spoken well, in saying, ‘I have no husband.’
verses.textLa: Respondit mulier, et dixit: Non habeo virum. Dicit ei Iesus: Bene dixisti, quia non habeo virum:

verses.textEn: For you have had five husbands, but he whom you have now is not your husband. You have spoken this in truth.”
verses.textLa: quinque enim viros habuisti, et nunc, quem habes, non est tuus vir: hoc vere dixisti.

verses.textEn: The woman said to him: “Lord, I see that you are a Prophet.
verses.textLa: Dicit ei mulier: Domine, video quia Propheta es tu.

verses.textEn: Our fathers worshipped on this mountain, but you say that Jerusalem is the place where one ought to worship.”
verses.textLa: Patres nostri in monte hoc adoraverunt, et vos dicitis, quia Ierosolymis est locus, ubi adorare oportet.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to her: “Woman, believe me, the hour is coming when you shall worship the Father, neither on this mountain, nor in Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Iesus: Mulier crede mihi, quia venit hora, quando neque in monte hoc, neque in Ierosolymis adorabitis Patrem.

verses.textEn: You worship what you do not know; we worship what we do know. For salvation is from the Jews.
verses.textLa: Vos adoratis quod nescitis: nos adoramus quod scimus, quia salus ex Iudæis est.

verses.textEn: But the hour is coming, and it is now, when true worshippers shall worship the Father in spirit and in truth. For the Father also seeks such persons who may worship him.
verses.textLa: Sed venit hora, et nunc est, quando veri adoratores adorabunt Patrem in spiritu et veritate. Nam et Pater tales quærit, qui adorent eum.

verses.textEn: God is Spirit. And so, those who worship him must worship in spirit and in truth.”
verses.textLa: Spiritus est Deus: et eos qui adorant eum, in spiritu et veritate oportet adorare.

verses.textEn: The woman said to him: “I know that the Messiah is coming (who is called the Christ). And then, when he will have arrived, he will announce everything to us.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei mulier: Scio quia Messias venit, (qui dicitur Christus.) cum ergo venerit ille, nobis annunciabit omnia.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to her: “I am he, the one who is speaking with you.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Iesus: Ego sum, qui loquor tecum.

verses.textEn: And then his disciples arrived. And they wondered that he was speaking with the woman. Yet no one said: “What are you seeking?” or, “Why are you talking with her?”
verses.textLa: Et continuo venerunt discipuli eius: et mirabantur quia cum muliere loquebatur. Nemo tamen dixit: Quid quæris, aut Quid loqueris cum ea?

verses.textEn: And so the woman left behind her water jar and went into the city. And she said to the men there:
verses.textLa: Reliquit ergo hydriam suam mulier, et abiit in civitatem, et dicit illis hominibus:

verses.textEn: “Come and see a man who has told me all the things that I have done. Is he not the Christ?”
verses.textLa: Venite, et videte hominem, qui dixit mihi omnia quæcumque feci: Numquid ipse est Christus?

verses.textEn: Therefore, they went out of the city and came to him.
verses.textLa: Exierunt ergo de civitate, et veniebant ad eum.

verses.textEn: Meanwhile, the disciples petitioned him, saying, “Rabbi, eat.”
verses.textLa: Interea rogabant eum discipuli, dicentes: Rabbi, manduca.

verses.textEn: But he said to them, “I have food to eat which you do not know.”
verses.textLa: Ille autem dicit eis: Ego cibum habeo manducare, quem vos nescitis.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the disciples said to one another, “Could someone have brought him something to eat?”
verses.textLa: Dicebant ergo discipuli ad invicem: Numquid aliquis attulit ei manducare?

verses.textEn: Jesus said to them: “My food is to do the will of the One who sent me, so that I may perfect his work.
verses.textLa: Dicit eis Iesus: Meus cibus est ut faciam voluntatem eius, qui misit me, ut perficiam opus eius.

verses.textEn: Do you not say, ‘There are still four months, and then the harvest arrives?’ Behold, I say to you: Lift up your eyes and look at the countryside; for it is already ripe for the harvest.
verses.textLa: Nonne vos dicitis, Quod adhuc quattuor menses sunt, et messis venit? Ecce, dico vobis: Levate oculos vestros, et videte regiones, quia albæ sunt iam ad messem.
verses.notes: The verse literally says ‘white’ rather than ‘ripe,’ with whiteness indicating that the harvest is ready. And this is probably not a literal whiteness to the grain, but rather a lighter color to the ripe grain fields.

verses.textEn: For he who reaps, receives wages and gathers fruit unto eternal life, so that both he who sows and he who reaps may rejoice together.
verses.textLa: Et qui metit, mercedem accipit, et congregat fructum in vitam æternam: ut, et qui seminat, simul gaudeat, et qui metit.

verses.textEn: For in this the word is true: that it is one who sows, and it is another who reaps.
verses.textLa: In hoc enim est verbum verum: quia alius est qui seminat, et alius est qui metit.

verses.textEn: I have sent you to reap that for which you did not labor. Others have labored, and you have entered into their labors.”
verses.textLa: Ego misi vos metere quod vos non laborastis: alii laboraverunt, et vos in labores eorum introistis.

verses.textEn: Now many of the Samaritans from that city believed in him, because of the word of the woman who was offering testimony: “For he told me all the things that I have done.”
verses.textLa: Ex civitate autem illa multi crediderunt in eum Samaritanorum, propter verbum mulieris testimonium perhibentis: Quia dixit mihi omnia quæcumque feci.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when the Samaritans had come to him, they petitioned him to lodge there. And he lodged there for two days.
verses.textLa: Cum venissent ergo ad illum Samaritani, rogaverunt eum ut ibi maneret. Et mansit ibi duos dies.

verses.textEn: And many more believed in him, because of his own word.
verses.textLa: Et multo plures crediderunt in eum propter sermonem eius.

verses.textEn: And they said to the woman: “Now we believe, not because of your speech, but because we ourselves have heard him, and so we know that he is truly the Savior of the world.”
verses.textLa: Et mulieri dicebant: Quia iam non propter tuam loquelam credimus: ipsi enim audivimus, et scimus quia hic est vere Salvator mundi.

verses.textEn: Then, after two days, he departed from there, and he traveled into Galilee.
verses.textLa: Post duos autem dies exiit inde: et abiit in Galilæam.

verses.textEn: For Jesus himself offered testimony that a Prophet has no honor in his own country.
verses.textLa: Ipse enim Iesus testimonium perhibuit quia Propheta in sua patria honorem non habet.

verses.textEn: And so, when he had arrived in Galilee, the Galileans received him, because they had seen all that he had done at Jerusalem, in the day of the feast. For they also went to the feast day.
verses.textLa: Cum ergo venisset in Galilæam, exceperunt eum Galilæi, cum omnia vidissent quæ fecerat Ierosolymis in die festo: et ipsi enim venerant ad diem festum.
verses.notes: They welcomed him in Galilee, having seen signs in Judea, therefore, as a prophet, He was accepted for signs he did in another region, not for what he had done in Galilee.

verses.textEn: Then he went again into Cana of Galilee, where he made water into wine. And there was a certain ruler, whose son was sick at Capernaum.
verses.textLa: Venit ergo iterum in Cana Galilææ, ubi fecit aquam vinum. Et erat quidam regulus, cuius filius infirmabatur Capharnaum.

verses.textEn: Since he had heard that Jesus came to Galilee from Judea, he sent to him and begged him to come down and heal his son. For he was beginning to die.
verses.textLa: Hic cum audisset quia Iesus adveniret a Iudæa in Galilæam, abiit ad eum, et rogabat eum ut descenderet, et sanaret filium eius: incipiebat enim mori.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Jesus said to him, “Unless you have seen signs and wonders, you do not believe.”
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo Iesus ad eum: Nisi signa, et prodigia videritis, non creditis.

verses.textEn: The ruler said to him, “Lord, come down before my son dies.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ad eum regulus: Domine, descende prius quam moriatur filius meus.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to him, “Go, your son lives.” The man believed the word that Jesus spoke to him, and so he went away.
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Iesus: Vade, filius tuus vivit. Credidit homo sermoni, quem dixit ei Iesus, et ibat.

verses.textEn: Then, as he was going down, his servants met him. And they reported to him, saying that his son was alive.
verses.textLa: Iam autem eo descendente, servi occurrerunt ei, et nunciaverunt dicentes, quia filius eius viveret.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he asked them at which hour he had become better. And they said to him, “Yesterday, at the seventh hour, the fever left him.”
verses.textLa: Interrogabat ergo horam ab eis, in qua melius habuerit. Et dixerunt ei: Quia heri hora septima reliquit eum febris.

verses.textEn: Then the father realized that it was at the same hour that Jesus said to him, “Your son lives.” And both he and his entire household believed.
verses.textLa: Cognovit ergo pater, quia illa hora erat, in qua dixit ei Iesus: Filius tuus vivit: et credidit ipse, et domus eius tota.

verses.textEn: This next sign was the second that Jesus accomplished, after he had arrived in Galilee from Judea.
verses.textLa: Hoc iterum secundum signum fecit Iesus, cum venisset a Iudæa in Galilæam.

verses.textEn: After these things, there was a feast day of the Jews, and so Jesus ascended to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Post hæc erat dies festus Iudæorum, et ascendit Iesus Ierosolymam.

verses.textEn: Now at Jerusalem is the Pool of Evidence, which in Hebrew is known as the Place of Mercy; it has five porticos.
verses.textLa: Est autem Ierosolymis Probatica piscina, quæ cognominatur Hebraice Bethesda, quinque porticus habens.
verses.notes: The word Probatica in Latin certainly refers to evidence or proof of something. This pool was proof of the existence of Angels. In Hebrew, the term is most likely 'Bethesda' (Place of Mercy). The five porticos are symbolic of the Five Wounds of Christ, which have the power to heal us in body and soul.

verses.textEn: Along these lay a great multitude of the sick, the blind, the lame, and the withered, waiting for the movement of the water.
verses.textLa: In his iacebat multitudo magna languentium, cæcorum, claudorum, aridorum expectantium aquæ motum.

verses.textEn: Now at times an Angel of the Lord would descend into the pool, and so the water was moved. And whoever descended first into the pool, after the motion of the water, he was healed of whatever infirmity held him.
verses.textLa: Angelus autem Domini descendebat secundum tempus in piscinam: et movebatur aqua. Et qui prior descendisset in piscinam post motionem aquæ, sanus fiebat a quacumque detinebatur infirmitate.

verses.textEn: And there was a certain man in that place, having been in his infirmity for thirty-eight years.
verses.textLa: Erat autem quidam homo ibi triginta et octo annos habens in infirmitate sua.

verses.textEn: Then, when Jesus had seen him reclining, and when he realized that he had been afflicted for a long time, he said to him, “Do you want to be healed?”
verses.textLa: Hunc autem cum vidisset Iesus iacentem, et cognovisset quia iam multum tempus haberet, dicit ei: Vis sanus fieri?

verses.textEn: The invalid answered him: “Lord, I do not have any man to put me in the pool, when the water has been stirred. For as I am going, another descends ahead of me.”
verses.textLa: Respondit ei languidus: Domine, hominem non habeo, ut cum turbata fuerit aqua, mittat me in piscinam: dum venio enim ego, alius ante me descendit.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to him, “Rise, take up your stretcher, and walk.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Iesus: Surge, tolle grabatum tuum, et ambula:

verses.textEn: And immediately the man was healed. And he took up his stretcher and walked. Now this day was the Sabbath.
verses.textLa: Et statim sanus factus est homo ille: et sustulit grabatum suum, et ambulabat. Erat autem Sabbatum in die illo.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the Jews said to the one who had been healed: “It is the Sabbath. It is not lawful for you to take up your stretcher.”
verses.textLa: Dicebant ergo Iudæi illi, qui sanatus fuerat: Sabbatum est, non licet tibi tollere grabatum tuum.

verses.textEn: He answered them, “The one who healed me, he said to me, ‘Take up your stretcher and walk.’ ”
verses.textLa: Respondit eis: Qui me sanum fecit, ille mihi dixit: Tolle grabatum tuum, et ambula.

verses.textEn: Therefore, they questioned him, “Who is that man, who said to you, ‘Take up your bed and walk?’ ”
verses.textLa: Interrogaverunt ergo eum: Quis est ille homo, qui dixit tibi: Tolle grabatum tuum, et ambula?

verses.textEn: But the one who had been given health did not know who it was. For Jesus had turned aside from the crowd gathered in that place.
verses.textLa: Is autem, qui sanus fuerat effectus, nesciebat quis esset. Iesus enim declinavit a turba constituta in loco.

verses.textEn: Afterwards, Jesus found him in the temple, and he said to him: “Behold, you have been healed. Do not choose to sin further, otherwise something worse may happen to you.”
verses.textLa: Postea invenit eum Iesus in templo, et dixit illi: Ecce sanus factus es: iam noli peccare, ne deterius tibi aliquid contingat.

verses.textEn: This man went away, and he reported to the Jews that it was Jesus who had given him health.
verses.textLa: Abiit ille homo, et nunciavit Iudæis quia Iesus esset, qui fecit eum sanum.

verses.textEn: Because of this, the Jews were persecuting Jesus, for he was doing these things on the Sabbath.
verses.textLa: Propterea persequebantur Iudæi Iesum, quia hæc faciebat in sabbato.

verses.textEn: But Jesus answered them, “Even now, my Father is working, and I am working.”
verses.textLa: Iesus autem respondit eis: Pater meus usque modo operatur, et ego operor.

verses.textEn: And so, because of this, the Jews were seeking to kill him even more so. For not only did he break the Sabbath, but he even said that God was his Father, making himself equal to God.
verses.textLa: Propterea ergo magis quærebant eum Iudæi interficere: quia non solum solvebat Sabbatum, sed et Patrem suum dicebat Deum, æqualem se faciens Deo.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus responded and said to them: “Amen, amen, I say to you, the Son is not able to do anything of himself, but only what he has seen the Father doing. For whatever he does, even this does the Son do, similarly.
verses.textLa: Respondit itaque Iesus, et dixit eis: Amen, amen dico vobis: non potest Filius a se facere quidquam, nisi quod viderit Patrem facientem: quæcumque enim ille fecerit, hæc et Filius similiter facit.

verses.textEn: For the Father loves the Son, and he shows him all that he himself does. And greater works than these will he show him, so much so that you shall wonder.
verses.textLa: Pater enim diligit Filium, et omnia demonstrat ei, quæ ipse facit: et maiora his demonstrabit ei opera, ut vos miremini.

verses.textEn: For just as the Father raises the dead and gives life, so also does the Son give life to whomever he wills.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim Pater suscitat mortuos, et vivificat: sic et Filius, quos vult, vivificat.

verses.textEn: For the Father does not judge anyone. But he has given all judgment to the Son,
verses.textLa: Neque enim Pater iudicat quemquam: sed omne iudicium dedit Filio,

verses.textEn: so that all may honor the Son, just as they honor the Father. Whoever does not honor the Son, does not honor the Father who sent him.
verses.textLa: ut omnes honorificent Filium, sicut honorificant Patrem: qui non honorificat Filium, non honorificat Patrem, qui misit illum.

verses.textEn: Amen, amen, I say to you, that whoever hears my word, and believes in him who sent me, has eternal life, and he does not go into judgment, but instead he crosses from death into life.
verses.textLa: Amen, amen dico vobis, quia qui verbum meum audit, et credit ei, qui misit me, habet vitam æternam, et in iudicium non venit, sed transiit a morte in vitam.

verses.textEn: Amen, amen, I say to you, that the hour is coming, and it is now, when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God; and those who hear it shall live.
verses.textLa: Amen, amen dico vobis, quia venit hora, et nunc est, quando mortui audient vocem Filii Dei: et qui audierint, vivent.

verses.textEn: For just as the Father has life in himself, so also has he granted to the Son to have life in himself.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim Pater habet vitam in semetipso: sic dedit et Filio habere vitam in semetipso:

verses.textEn: And he has given him the authority to accomplish judgment. For he is the Son of man.
verses.textLa: et potestatem dedit ei iudicium facere, quia Filius hominis est.

verses.textEn: Do not be amazed at this. For the hour is coming in which all who are in the grave shall hear the voice of the Son of God.
verses.textLa: Nolite mirari hoc, quia venit hora, in qua omnes, qui in monumentis sunt, audient vocem Filii Dei:

verses.textEn: And those who have done good shall go forth to the resurrection of life. Yet truly, those who have done evil shall go to the resurrection of judgment.
verses.textLa: et procedent qui bona fecerunt, in resurrectionem vitæ: qui vero mala egerunt, in resurrectionem iudicii.

verses.textEn: I am not able to do anything of myself. As I hear, so do I judge. And my judgment is just. For I do not seek my own will, but the will of him who sent me.
verses.textLa: Non possum ego a meipso facere quidquam. Sicut audio, iudico: et iudicium meum iustum est: quia non quæro voluntatem meam, sed voluntatem eius, qui misit me.

verses.textEn: If I offer testimony about myself, my testimony is not true.
verses.textLa: Si ego testimonium perhibeo de meipso, testimonium meum non est verum.

verses.textEn: There is another who offers testimony about me, and I know that the testimony which he offers about me is true.
verses.textLa: Alius est, qui testimonium perhibet de me: et scio quia verum est testimonium, quod perhibet de me.

verses.textEn: You sent to John, and he offered testimony to the truth.
verses.textLa: Vos misistis ad Ioannem: et testimonium perhibuit veritati.

verses.textEn: But I do not accept testimony from man. Instead, I say these things, so that you may be saved.
verses.textLa: Ego autem non ab homine testimonium accipio: sed hæc dico ut vos salvi sitis.

verses.textEn: He was a burning and shining light. So you were willing, at the time, to exult in his light.
verses.textLa: Ille erat lucerna ardens, et lucens. Vos autem voluistis ad horam exultare in luce eius.

verses.textEn: But I hold a greater testimony than that of John. For the works which the Father has given to me, so that I may complete them, these works themselves that I do, offer testimony about me: that the Father has sent me.
verses.textLa: Ego autem habeo testimonium maius Ioanne. Opera enim, quæ dedit mihi Pater ut perficiam ea: ipsa opera, quæ ego facio, testimonium perhibent de me, quia Pater misit me:

verses.textEn: And the Father who has sent me has himself offered testimony about me. And you have never heard his voice, nor have you beheld his appearance.
verses.textLa: et qui misit me Pater, ipse testimonium perhibuit de me: neque vocem eius umquam audistis, neque speciem eius vidistis.

verses.textEn: And you do not have his word abiding in you. For the one whom he sent, the same you would not believe.
verses.textLa: Et verbum eius non habetis in vobis manens: quia quem misit ille, huic vos non creditis.

verses.textEn: Study the Scriptures. For you think that in them you have eternal life. And yet they also offer testimony about me.
verses.textLa: Scrutamini Scripturas, quia vos putatis in ipsis vitam æternam habere: et illæ sunt, quæ testimonium perhibent de me:

verses.textEn: And you are not willing to come to me, so that you may have life.
verses.textLa: et non vultis venire ad me ut vitam habeatis.

verses.textEn: I do not accept glory from men.
verses.textLa: Claritatem ab hominibus non accipio.

verses.textEn: But I know you, that you do not have the love of God within you.
verses.textLa: Sed cognovi vos, quia dilectionem Dei non habetis in vobis.

verses.textEn: I have come in the name of my Father, and you do not accept me. If another will arrive in his own name, him you will accept.
verses.textLa: Ego veni in nomine Patris mei, et non accipitis me: si alius venerit in nomine suo, illum accipietis.
verses.notes: This last part refers to the Antichrist. Those who reject Christ, who comes in the name of the Father, will accept the Antichrist, who exalts himself and who comes in his own name.

verses.textEn: How are you able to believe, you who accept glory from one another and yet do not seek the glory that is from God alone?
verses.textLa: Quomodo vos potestis credere, qui gloriam ab invicem accipitis: et gloriam, quæ a solo Deo est, non quæritis?

verses.textEn: Do not consider that I might accuse you with the Father. There is one who accuses you, Moses, in whom you hope.
verses.textLa: Nolite putare quia ego accusaturus sim vos apud Patrem. Est qui accusat vos Moyses, in quo vos speratis.

verses.textEn: For if you were believing in Moses, perhaps you would believe in me also. For he wrote about me.
verses.textLa: Si enim crederetis Moysi, crederetis forsitan et mihi: de me enim ille scripsit.

verses.textEn: But if you do not believe by his writings, how will you believe by my words?”
verses.textLa: Si autem illius litteris non creditis: quomodo verbis meis credetis?

verses.textEn: After these things, Jesus traveled across the sea of Galilee, which is the Sea of Tiberias.
verses.textLa: Post hæc abiit Iesus trans mare Galilææ, quod est Tiberiadis:

verses.textEn: And a great multitude was following him, for they saw the signs that he was accomplishing toward those who were infirm.
verses.textLa: et sequebatur eum multitudo magna, quia videbant signa, quæ faciebat super his, qui infirmabantur.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Jesus went onto a mountain, and he sat down there with his disciples.
verses.textLa: Subiit ergo in montem Iesus: et ibi sedebat cum discipulis suis.

verses.textEn: Now the Passover, the feast day of the Jews, was near.
verses.textLa: Erat autem proximum Pascha dies festus Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: And so, when Jesus had lifted up his eyes and had seen that a very great multitude came to him, he said to Philip, “From where should we buy bread, so that these may eat?”
verses.textLa: Cum sublevasset ergo oculos Iesus, et vidisset quia multitudo maxima venit ad eum, dixit ad Philippum: Unde ememus panes, ut manducent hi?

verses.textEn: But he said this to test him. For he himself knew what he would do.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem dicebat tentans eum: ipse enim sciebat quid esset facturus.

verses.textEn: Philip answered him, “Two hundred denarii of bread would not be sufficient for each of them to receive even a little.”
verses.textLa: Respondit ei Philippus: Ducentorum denariorum panes non sufficiunt eis, ut unusquisque modicum quid accipiat.

verses.textEn: One of his disciples, Andrew, the brother of Simon Peter, said to him:
verses.textLa: Dicit ei unus ex discipulis eius, Andreas frater Simonis Petri:

verses.textEn: “There is a certain boy here, who has five barley loaves and two fish. But what are these among so many?”
verses.textLa: Est puer unus hic, qui habet quinque panes hordeaceos, et duos pisces: sed hæc quid sunt inter tantos?

verses.textEn: Then Jesus said, “Have the men sit down to eat.” Now, there was much grass in that place. And so the men, in number about five thousand, sat down to eat.
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo Iesus: Facite homines discumbere. Erat autem fœnum multum in loco. Discumberunt ergo viri, numero quasi quinque millia.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Jesus took the bread, and when he had given thanks, he distributed it to those who were sitting down to eat; similarly also, from the fish, as much as they wanted.
verses.textLa: Accepit ergo Iesus panes: et cum gratias egisset, distribuit discumbentibus: similiter et ex piscibus quantum volebant.

verses.textEn: Then, when they were filled, he said to his disciples, “Gather the fragments that are left over, lest they be lost.”
verses.textLa: Ut autem impleti sunt, dixit discipulis suis: Colligite quæ superaverunt fragmenta, ne pereant.

verses.textEn: And so they gathered, and they filled twelve baskets with the fragments of the five barley loaves, which were left over from those who had eaten.
verses.textLa: Collegerunt ergo, et impleverunt duodecim cophinos fragmentorum ex quinque panibus hordeaceis, quæ superfuerunt his, qui manducaverant.

verses.textEn: Therefore, those men, when they had seen that Jesus had accomplished a sign, they said, “Truly, this one is the Prophet who is to come into the world.”
verses.textLa: Illi ergo homines cum vidissent quod Iesus fecerat signum, dicebant: Quia hic est vere propheta, qui venturus est in mundum.

verses.textEn: And so, when he realized that they were going to come and take him away and make him king, Jesus fled back to the mountain, by himself alone.
verses.textLa: Iesus ergo cum cognovisset quia venturi essent ut raperent eum, et facerent eum regem, fugit iterum in montem ipse solus.

verses.textEn: Then, when evening arrived, his disciples descended to the sea.
verses.textLa: Ut autem sero factum est, descenderunt discipuli eius ad mare.

verses.textEn: And when they had climbed into a boat, they went across the sea to Capernaum. And darkness had now arrived, and Jesus had not returned to them.
verses.textLa: Et cum ascendissent navim, venerunt trans mare in Capharnaum: et tenebræ iam factæ erant: et non venerat ad eos Iesus.

verses.textEn: Then the sea was stirred up by a great wind that was blowing.
verses.textLa: Mare autem, vento magno flante, exsurgebat.

verses.textEn: And so, when they had rowed about twenty-five or thirty stadia, they saw Jesus walking on the sea, and drawing near to the boat, and they were afraid.
verses.textLa: Cum remigassent ergo quasi stadia viginti quinque aut triginta, vident Iesum ambulantem supra mare, et proximum navi fieri, et timuerunt.

verses.textEn: But he said to them: “It is I. Do not be afraid.”
verses.textLa: Ille autem dicit eis: Ego sum, nolite timere.

verses.textEn: Therefore, they were willing to receive him into the boat. But immediately the boat was at the land to which they were going.
verses.textLa: Voluerunt ergo accipere eum in navim: et statim navis fuit ad terram, in quam ibant.

verses.textEn: On the next day, the crowd which was standing across the sea saw that there were no other small boats in that place, except one, and that Jesus had not entered into the boat with his disciples, but that his disciples had departed alone.
verses.textLa: Altera die, turba, quæ stabat trans mare, vidit quia navicula alia non erat ibi nisi una, et quia non introisset cum discipulis suis Iesus in navim, sed soli discipuli eius abiissent:

verses.textEn: Yet truly, other boats came over from Tiberias, next to the place where they had eaten the bread after the Lord gave thanks.
verses.textLa: aliæ vero supervenerunt naves a Tiberiade iuxta locum ubi manducaverunt panem, gratias agente Domino.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when the crowd had seen that Jesus was not there, nor his disciples, they climbed into the small boats, and they went to Capernaum, seeking Jesus.
verses.textLa: Cum ergo vidisset turba quia Iesus non esset ibi, neque discipuli eius, ascenderunt in naviculas, et venerunt Capharnaum quærentes Iesum.

verses.textEn: And when they had found him across the sea, they said to him, “Rabbi, when did you come here?”
verses.textLa: Et cum invenissent eum trans mare, dixerunt ei: Rabbi, quando huc venisti?

verses.textEn: Jesus answered them and said: “Amen, amen, I say to you, you seek me, not because you have seen signs, but because you have eaten from the bread and were satisfied.
verses.textLa: Respondit eis Iesus, et dixit: Amen, amen dico vobis: quæritis me non quia vidistis signa, sed quia manducastis ex panibus, et saturati estis.

verses.textEn: Do not work for food that perishes, but for that which endures to eternal life, which the Son of man will give to you. For God the Father has sealed him.”
verses.textLa: Operamini non cibum, qui perit, sed qui permanet in vitam æternam, quem Filius hominis dabit vobis. Hunc enim Pater signavit Deus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, they said to him, “What should we do, so that we may labor in the works of God?”
verses.textLa: Dixerunt ergo ad eum: Quid faciemus ut operemur opera Dei?

verses.textEn: Jesus responded and said to them, “This is the work of God, that you believe in him whom he sent.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus, et dixit eis: Hoc est opus Dei, ut credatis in eum quem misit ille.

verses.textEn: And so they said to him: “Then what sign will you do, so that we may see it and believe in you? What will you work?
verses.textLa: Dixerunt ergo ei: Quod ergo tu facis signum ut videamus, et credamus tibi? Quid operaris?

verses.textEn: Our fathers ate manna in the desert, just as it has been written, ‘He gave them bread from heaven to eat.’ ”
verses.textLa: Patres nostri manducaverunt manna in deserto, sicut scriptum est: Panem de cælo dedit eis manducare.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Jesus said to them: “Amen, amen, I say to you, Moses did not give you bread from heaven, but my Father gives you the true bread from heaven.
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo eis Iesus: Amen, amen dico vobis: Non Moyses dedit vobis panem de cælo, sed Pater meus dat vobis panem de cælo verum.

verses.textEn: For the bread of God is he who descends from heaven and gives life to the world.”
verses.textLa: Panis enim Dei est, qui de cælo descendit, et dat vitam mundo.

verses.textEn: And so they said to him, “Lord, give us this bread always.”
verses.textLa: Dixerunt ergo ad eum: Domine, semper da nobis panem hunc.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus said to them: “I am the bread of life. Whoever comes to me shall not hunger, and whoever believes in me shall never thirst.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem eis Iesus: Ego sum panis vitæ: qui venit ad me, non esuriet, et qui credit in me, non sitiet umquam.
verses.notes: Notice that coming to Jesus is not as effective as believing in him. The one who comes to him shall not hunger, but those who believe shall not thirst ever. The world umquam is added because coming to him is not enough to be satisfied forever in eternity; one must also believe.

verses.textEn: But I say to you, that even though you have seen me, you do not believe.
verses.textLa: Sed dixi vobis quia et vidistis me, et non creditis.

verses.textEn: All that the Father gives to me shall come to me. And whoever comes to me, I will not cast out.
verses.textLa: Omne quod dat mihi Pater, ad me veniet: et eum, qui venit ad me, non eiiciam foras:

verses.textEn: For I descended from heaven, not to do my own will, but the will of him who sent me.
verses.textLa: quia descendi de cælo, non ut faciam voluntatem meam, sed voluntatem eius, qui misit me.

verses.textEn: Yet this is the will of the Father who sent me: that I should lose nothing out of all that he has given to me, but that I should raise them up on the last day.
verses.textLa: Hæc est autem voluntas eius, qui misit me, Patris: ut omne, quod dedit mihi, non perdam ex eo, sed resuscitem illud in novissimo die.

verses.textEn: So then, this is the will of my Father who sent me: that everyone who sees the Son and believes in him may have eternal life, and I will raise him up on the last day.”
verses.textLa: Hæc est autem voluntas Patris mei, qui misit me: ut omnis, qui videt Filium, et credit in eum, habeat vitam æternam, et ego resuscitabo eum in novissimo die.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the Jews murmured about him, because he had said: “I am the living bread, who descended from heaven.”
verses.textLa: Murmurabant ergo Iudæi de illo, quia dixisset: Ego sum panis vivus, qui de cælo descendi,
verses.notes: The verb ‘descendi’ is here first person singular perfect active indicative, not infinitive, because the phrase ‘Ego sum’ (I am) in effect makes the word ‘qui’ (who) first person singular.

verses.textEn: And they said: “Is this not Jesus, the son of Joseph, whose father and mother we know? Then how can he say: ‘For I descended from heaven?’ ”
verses.textLa: et dicebant: Nonne hic est Iesus filius Ioseph, cuius nos novimus patrem, et matrem? Quomodo ergo dicit hic: Quia de cælo descendi?

verses.textEn: And so Jesus responded and said to them: “Do not choose to murmur among yourselves.
verses.textLa: Respondit ergo Iesus, et dixit eis: Nolite murmurare in invicem:

verses.textEn: No one is able to come to me, unless the Father, who has sent me, has drawn him. And I will raise him up on the last day.
verses.textLa: nemo potest venire ad me, nisi Pater, qui misit me, traxerit eum: et ego resuscitabo eum in novissimo die.

verses.textEn: It has been written in the Prophets: ‘And they shall all be taught by God.’ Everyone who has listened and learned from the Father comes to me.
verses.textLa: Est scriptum in Prophetis: Et erunt omnes docibiles Dei. Omnis, qui audivit a Patre, et didicit, venit ad me.
verses.notes: The use of the word ‘docibiles’ here is unusual. It could also be translated as ‘And they shall all be students of God.’

verses.textEn: Not that anyone has seen the Father, except he who is from God; this one has seen the Father.
verses.textLa: Non quia Patrem vidit quisquam, nisi is, qui est a Deo, hic vidit Patrem.

verses.textEn: Amen, amen, I say to you, whoever believes in me has eternal life.
verses.textLa: Amen, amen dico vobis: Qui credit in me, habet vitam æternam.

verses.textEn: I am the bread of life.
verses.textLa: Ego sum panis vitæ.

verses.textEn: Your fathers ate manna in the desert, and they died.
verses.textLa: Patres vestri manducaverunt manna in deserto, et mortui sunt.

verses.textEn: This is the bread which descends from heaven, so that if anyone will eat from it, he may not die.
verses.textLa: Hic est panis de cælo descendens: ut si quis ex ipso manducaverit, non moriatur.

verses.textEn: I am the living bread, who descended from heaven.
verses.textLa: Ego sum panis vivus, qui de cælo descendi.

verses.textEn: If anyone eats from this bread, he shall live in eternity. And the bread that I will give is my flesh, for the life of the world.”
verses.textLa: Si quis manducaverit ex hoc pane, vivet in æternum: et panis, quem ego dabo, caro mea est pro mundi vita.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the Jews debated among themselves, saying, “How can this man give us his flesh to eat?”
verses.textLa: Litigabant ergo Iudæi ad invicem, dicentes: Quomodo potest hic nobis carnem suam dare ad manducandum?

verses.textEn: And so, Jesus said to them: “Amen, amen, I say to you, unless you eat the flesh of the Son of man and drink his blood, you will not have life in you.
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo eis Iesus: Amen, amen dico vobis: Nisi manducaveritis carnem Filii hominis, et biberitis eius sanguinem, non habebitis vitam in vobis.

verses.textEn: Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood has eternal life, and I will raise him up on the last day.
verses.textLa: Qui manducat meam carnem, et bibit meum sanguinem, habet vitam æternam: et ego resuscitabo eum in novissimo die.

verses.textEn: For my flesh is true food, and my blood is true drink.
verses.textLa: Caro enim mea, vere est cibus: et sanguis meus, vere est potus.

verses.textEn: Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood abides in me, and I in him.
verses.textLa: Qui manducat meam carnem, et bibit meum sanguinem, in me manet, et ego in illo.

verses.textEn: Just as the living Father has sent me and I live because of the Father, so also whoever eats me, the same shall live because of me.
verses.textLa: Sicut misit me vivens Pater, et ego vivo propter Patrem: et qui manducat me, et ipse vivet propter me.

verses.textEn: This is the bread that descends from heaven. It is not like the manna that your fathers ate, for they died. Whoever eats this bread shall live forever.”
verses.textLa: Hic est panis, qui de cælo descendit. Non sicut manducaverunt patres vestri manna, et mortui sunt. Qui manducat hunc panem, vivet in æternum.

verses.textEn: He said these things when he was teaching in the synagogue at Capernaum.
verses.textLa: Hæc dixit in synagoga docens in Capharnaum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, many of his disciples, upon hearing this, said: “This saying is difficult,” and, “Who is able to listen to it?”
verses.textLa: Multi ergo audientes ex discipulis eius, dixerunt: Durus est hic sermo, et quis potest eum audire?

verses.textEn: But Jesus, knowing within himself that his disciples were murmuring about this, said to them: “Does this offend you?
verses.textLa: Sciens autem Iesus apud semetipsum quia murmurarent de hoc discipuli eius, dixit eis: Hoc vos scandalizat?

verses.textEn: Then what if you were to see the Son of man ascending to where he was before?
verses.textLa: Si ergo videritis Filium hominis ascendentem ubi erat prius?

verses.textEn: It is the Spirit who gives life. The flesh does not offer anything of benefit. The words that I have spoken to you are spirit and life.
verses.textLa: Spiritus est, qui vivificat: caro non prodest quidquam. Verba, quæ ego locutus sum vobis, spiritus et vita sunt.
verses.notes: Without the grace and cooperation of the Holy Spirit, the Eucharist will not benefit those who receive it. The graces that come from receiving the Eucharist are received by a response to the graces of the Spirit, who gives life through the Eucharist.

verses.textEn: But there are some among you who do not believe.” For Jesus knew from the beginning who were unbelieving and which one would betray him.
verses.textLa: Sed sunt quidam ex vobis, qui non credunt. Sciebat enim ab initio Iesus qui essent non credentes, et quis traditurus esset eum.

verses.textEn: And so he said, “For this reason, I said to you that no one is able to come to me, unless it has been given to him by my Father.”
verses.textLa: Et dicebat: Propterea dixi vobis, quia nemo potest venire ad me, nisi fuerit ei datum a Patre meo.

verses.textEn: After this, many of his disciples went back, and they no longer walked with him.
verses.textLa: Ex hoc multi discipulorum eius abierunt retro: et iam non cum illo ambulabant.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Jesus said to the twelve, “Do you also want to go away?”
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo Iesus ad duodecim: Numquid et vos vultis abire?

verses.textEn: Then Simon Peter answered him: “Lord, to whom would we go? You have the words of eternal life.
verses.textLa: Respondit ergo ei Simon Petrus: Domine, ad quem ibimus? Verba vitæ æternæ habes.

verses.textEn: And we have believed, and we recognize that you are the Christ, the Son of God.”
verses.textLa: Et nos credidimus, et cognovimus quia tu es Christus Filius Dei.

verses.textEn: Jesus answered them: “Have I not chosen you twelve? And yet one among you is a devil.”
verses.textLa: Respondit eis Iesus: Nonne ego vos duodecim elegi: et ex vobis unus diabolus est?

verses.textEn: Now he was speaking about Judas Iscariot, the son of Simon. For this one, even though he was one of the twelve, was about to betray him.
verses.textLa: Dicebat autem Iudam Simonis Iscariotem: hic enim erat traditurus eum, cum esset unus ex duodecim.

verses.textEn: Then, after these things, Jesus was walking in Galilee. For he was not willing to walk in Judea, because the Jews were seeking to kill him.
verses.textLa: Post hæc autem ambulabat Iesus in Galilæam, non enim volebat in Iudæam ambulare: quia quærebant eum Iudæi interficere.

verses.textEn: Now the feast day of the Jews, the Feast of Tabernacles, was near.
verses.textLa: Erat autem in proximo dies festus Iudæorum, Scenopegia.

verses.textEn: And his brothers said to him: “Move away from here and go into Judea, so that your disciples there may also see your works that you do.
verses.textLa: Dixerunt autem ad eum fratres eius: Transi hinc, et vade in Iudæam, ut et discipuli tui videant opera tua, quæ facis.

verses.textEn: Of course, no one does anything in secret, but he himself seeks to be in the public view. Since you do these things, manifest yourself to the world.”
verses.textLa: Nemo quippe in occulto quid facit, et quærit ipse in palam esse: si hæc facis, manifesta teipsum mundo.

verses.textEn: For neither did his brothers believe in him.
verses.textLa: Neque enim fratres eius credebant in eum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Jesus said to them: “My time has not yet come; but your time is always at hand.
verses.textLa: Dicit ergo eis Iesus: Tempus meum nondum advenit: tempus autem vestrum semper est paratum.

verses.textEn: The world cannot hate you. But it hates me, because I offer testimony about it, that its works are evil.
verses.textLa: Non potest mundus odisse vos: me autem odit: quia ego testimonium perhibeo de illo quod opera eius mala sunt.

verses.textEn: You may go up to this feast day. But I am not going up to this feast day, because my time has not yet been fulfilled.”
verses.textLa: Vos ascendite ad diem festum hunc, ego autem non ascendo ad diem festum istum: quia meum tempus nondum impletum est.

verses.textEn: When he had said these things, he himself remained in Galilee.
verses.textLa: Hæc cum dixisset, ipse mansit in Galilæa.

verses.textEn: But after his brothers went up, then he also went up to the feast day, not openly, but as if in secret.
verses.textLa: Ut autem ascenderunt fratres eius, tunc et ipse ascendit ad diem festum non manifeste, sed quasi in occulto.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the Jews were seeking him on the feast day, and they were saying, “Where is he?”
verses.textLa: Iudæi ergo quærebant eum in die festo, et dicebant: Ubi est ille?

verses.textEn: And there was much murmuring in the crowd concerning him. For certain ones were saying, “He is good.” But others were saying, “No, for he seduces the crowds.”
verses.textLa: Et murmur multum erat in turba de eo. Quidam enim dicebant: Quia bonus est. Alii autem dicebant: Non, sed seducit turbas.

verses.textEn: Yet no one was speaking openly about him, out of fear of the Jews.
verses.textLa: Nemo tamen palam loquebatur de illo propter metum Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: Then, about the middle of the feast, Jesus ascended into the temple, and he was teaching.
verses.textLa: Iam autem die festo mediante, ascendit Iesus in templum, et docebat.

verses.textEn: And the Jews wondered, saying: “How does this one know letters, though he has not been taught?”
verses.textLa: Et mirabantur Iudæi, dicentes: Quomodo hic litteras scit, cum non didicerit?

verses.textEn: Jesus responded to them and said: “My doctrine is not of me, but of him who sent me.
verses.textLa: Respondit eis Iesus, et dixit: Mea doctrina non est mea, sed eius, qui misit me.

verses.textEn: If anyone has chosen to do his will, then he will realize, about the doctrine, whether it is from God, or whether I am speaking from myself.
verses.textLa: Si quis voluerit voluntatem eius facere: cognoscet de doctrina, utrum ex Deo sit, an ego a me ipso loquar.

verses.textEn: Whoever speaks from himself seeks his own glory. But whoever seeks the glory of him who sent him, this one is true, and injustice is not in him.
verses.textLa: Qui a semetipso loquitur, gloriam propriam quærit. Qui autem quærit gloriam eius, qui misit eum, hic verax est, et iniustitia in illo non est.

verses.textEn: Did not Moses give you the law? And yet not one among you keeps the law!
verses.textLa: Nonne Moyses dedit vobis legem: et nemo ex vobis facit legem?

verses.textEn: Why are you seeking to kill me?” The crowd responded and said: “You must have a demon. Who is seeking to kill you?”
verses.textLa: Quid me quæritis interficere? Respondit turba, et dixit: Dæmonium habes: quis te quæret interficere?

verses.textEn: Jesus responded and said to them: “One work have I done, and you all wonder.
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus, et dixit eis: Unum opus feci, et omnes miramini:

verses.textEn: For Moses gave you circumcision, (not that it is of Moses, but of the fathers) and on the Sabbath you circumcise a man.
verses.textLa: Propterea Moyses dedit vobis circumcisionem: (non quia ex Moyse est, sed ex patribus) et in Sabbato circumciditis hominem.

verses.textEn: If a man can receive circumcision on the Sabbath, so that the law of Moses may not be broken, why are you indignant toward me, because I have made a man whole on the Sabbath?
verses.textLa: Si circumcisionem accipit homo in Sabbato, ut non solvatur lex Moysi: mihi indignamini quia totum hominem sanum feci in Sabbato?

verses.textEn: Do not judge according to appearances, but instead judge a just judgment.”
verses.textLa: Nolite iudicare secundum faciem, sed iustum iudicium iudicate.

verses.textEn: Therefore, some of those from Jerusalem said: “Is he not the one whom they are seeking to kill?
verses.textLa: Dicebant ergo quidam ex Ierosolymis: Nonne hic est, quem quærunt interficere?

verses.textEn: And behold, he is speaking openly, and they say nothing to him. Could the leaders have decided that it is true this one is the Christ?
