verses.textLa: Si cognovissetis me, et Patrem meum utique cognovissetis: et amodo cognoscetis eum, et vidistis eum.

verses.textEn: Philip said to him, “Lord, reveal the Father to us, and it is enough for us.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Philippus: Domine, ostende nobis Patrem, et sufficit nobis.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to him: “Have I been with you for so long, and you have not known me? Philip, whoever sees me, also sees the Father. How can you say, ‘Reveal the Father to us?’
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Iesus: Tanto tempore vobiscum sum: et non cognovistis me? Philippe, qui videt me, videt et Patrem. Quomodo tu dicis: Ostende nobis Patrem?

verses.textEn: Do you not believe that I am in the Father and the Father is in me? The words that I am speaking to you, I do not speak from myself. But the Father abiding in me, he does these works.
verses.textLa: Non creditis quia ego in Patre, et Pater in me est? Verba, quæ ego loquor vobis, a me ipso non loquor. Pater autem in me manens, ipse fecit opera.

verses.textEn: Do you not believe that I am in the Father and the Father is in me?
verses.textLa: Non creditis quia ego in Patre, et Pater in me est?

verses.textEn: Or else, believe because of these same works. Amen, amen, I say to you, whoever believes in me shall also do the works that I do. And greater things than these shall he do, for I go to the Father.
verses.textLa: Alioquin propter opera ipsa credite. Amen, amen dico vobis, qui credit in me, opera, quæ ego facio, et ipse faciet, et maiora horum faciet: quia ego ad Patrem vado.

verses.textEn: And whatever you shall ask the Father in my name, that I will do, so that the Father may be glorified in the Son.
verses.textLa: Et quodcumque petieritis Patrem in nomine meo, hoc faciam: ut glorificetur Pater in Filio.

verses.textEn: If you shall ask anything of me in my name, that I will do.
verses.textLa: Si quid petieritis me in nomine meo, hoc faciam.

verses.textEn: If you love me, keep my commandments.
verses.textLa: Si diligitis me: mandata mea servate.

verses.textEn: And I will ask the Father, and he will give another Advocate to you, so that he may abide with you for eternity:
verses.textLa: Et ego rogabo Patrem, et alium Paraclitum dabit vobis, ut maneat vobiscum in æternum,
verses.notes: The word Paraclete is translated as Advocate, rather than leaving it as ‘Paraclete’ which then would need to be explained to many people. Generally, I think that words should be translated, even if they are place names or titles, wherever it would otherwise be unclear.

verses.textEn: the Spirit of Truth, whom the world is not able to accept, because it neither perceives him nor knows him. But you shall know him. For he will remain with you, and he will be in you.
verses.textLa: Spiritum veritatis, quem mundus non potest accipere, quia non videt eum, nec scit eum. Vos autem cognoscetis eum: quia apud vos manebit, et in vobis erit.

verses.textEn: I will not leave you orphans. I will return to you.
verses.textLa: Non relinquam vos orphanos: veniam ad vos.

verses.textEn: Yet a little while and the world will not see me any longer. But you will see me. For I live, and you shall live.
verses.textLa: Adhuc modicum: et mundus me iam non videt. Vos autem videtis me: quia ego vivo, et vos vivetis.

verses.textEn: In that day, you shall know that I am in my Father, and you are in me, and I am in you.
verses.textLa: In illo die vos cognoscetis quia ego sum in Patre meo, et vos in me, et ego in vobis.

verses.textEn: Whoever holds to my commandments and keeps them: it is he who loves me. And whoever loves me shall be loved by my Father. And I will love him, and I will manifest myself to him.”
verses.textLa: Qui habet mandata mea, et servat ea: ille est, qui diligit me. Qui autem diligit me, diligetur a Patre meo: et ego diligam eum, et manifestabo ei meipsum.

verses.textEn: Judas, not the Iscariot, said to him: “Lord, how does it happen that you will manifest yourself to us and not to the world?”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Iudas, non ille Iscariotes: Domine, quid factum est, quia manifestaturus es nobis tepisum, et non mundo?

verses.textEn: Jesus responded and said to him: “If anyone loves me, he shall keep my word. And my Father will love him, and we will come to him, and we will make our dwelling place with him.
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus, et dixit ei: Si quis diligit me, sermonem meum servabit, et Pater meus diliget eum, et ad eum veniemus, et mansionem apud eum faciemus:

verses.textEn: Whoever does not love me, does not keep not my words. And the word that you have heard is not of me, but it is of the Father who sent me.
verses.textLa: qui non diligit me, sermones meos non servat. Et sermonem, quem audistis, non est meus: sed eius, qui misit me, Patris.

verses.textEn: These things I have spoken to you, while abiding with you.
verses.textLa: Hæc locutus sum vobis apud vos manens.

verses.textEn: But the Advocate, the Holy Spirit, whom the Father will send in my name, will teach you all things and will suggest to you everything whatsoever that I have said to you.
verses.textLa: Paraclitus autem Spiritus Sanctus, quem mittet Pater in nomine meo, ille vos docebit omnia, et suggeret vobis omnia, quæcumque dixero vobis.

verses.textEn: Peace I leave for you; my Peace I give to you. Not in the way that the world gives, do I give to you. Do not let your heart be troubled, and let it not fear.
verses.textLa: Pacem relinquo vobis, pacem meam do vobis: non quomodo mundus dat, ego do vobis. Non turbetur cor vestrum, neque formidet.

verses.textEn: You have heard that I said to you: I am going away, and I am returning to you. If you loved me, certainly you would be gladdened, because I am going to the Father. For the Father is greater than I.
verses.textLa: Audistis quia ego dixi vobis: Vado, et venio ad vos. Si diligeretis me, gauderetis utique, quia vado ad Patrem: quia Pater maior me est.

verses.textEn: And now I have told you this, before it happens, so that, when it will happen, you may believe.
verses.textLa: Et nunc dixi vobis priusquam fiat: ut cum factum fuerit, credatis.

verses.textEn: I will not now speak at length with you. For the prince of this world is coming, but he does not have anything in me.
verses.textLa: Iam non multa loquar vobiscum. Venit enim princeps mundi huius, et in me non habet quidquam.

verses.textEn: Yet this is so that the world may know that I love the Father, and that I am acting according to the commandment that the Father has given to me. Rise up, let us go from here.”
verses.textLa: Sed ut cognoscat mundus quia diligo Patrem, et sicut mandatum dedit mihi Pater, sic facio. Surgite, eamus hinc.

verses.textEn: “I am the true vine, and my Father is the vinedresser.
verses.textLa: Ego sum vitis vera: et Pater meus agricola est.
verses.notes: The word ‘agricola’ really does not mean ‘vinedresser.’ It has more of a general meaning, like ‘farmer’ or ‘gardener.’ But context is very important to an accurate translation, and in this context of ‘vines,’ the person caring for the vines is called a ‘vinedresser.’

verses.textEn: Every branch in me that does not bear fruit, he will take away. And each one that does bear fruit, he will cleanse, so that it may bring forth more fruit.
verses.textLa: Omnem palmitem in me non ferentem fructum, tollet eum: et omnem, qui fert fructum, purgabit eum, ut fructum plus afferat.

verses.textEn: You are clean now, because of the word that I have spoken to you.
verses.textLa: Iam vos mundi estis propter sermonem, quem locutus sum vobis.

verses.textEn: Abide in me, and I in you. Just as the branch is not able to bear fruit of itself, unless it abides in the vine, so also are you unable, unless you abide in me.
verses.textLa: Manete in me: et ego in vobis. Sicut palmes non potest fere fructum a semetipso, nisi manserit in vite: sic nec vos, nisi in me manseritis.

verses.textEn: I am the vine; you are the branches. Whoever abides in me, and I in him, bears much fruit. For without me, you are able to do nothing.
verses.textLa: Ego sum vitis, vos palmites: qui manet in me, et ego in eo, hic fert fructum multum: quia sine me nihil potestis facere.

verses.textEn: If anyone does not abide in me, he will be cast away, like a branch, and he will wither, and they will gather him and cast him into the fire, and he burns.
verses.textLa: Si quis in me non manserit: mittetur foras sicut palmes, et arescet, et colligent eum, et in ignem mittent, et ardet.

verses.textEn: If you abide in me, and my words abide in you, then you may ask for whatever you will, and it shall be done for you.
verses.textLa: Si manseritis in me, et verba mea in vobis manserint: quodcumque volueritis petetis, et fiet vobis.

verses.textEn: In this, my Father is glorified: that you should bring forth very much fruit and become my disciples.
verses.textLa: In hoc clarificatus est Pater meus, ut fructum plurimum afferatis, et efficiamini mei discipuli.

verses.textEn: As the Father has loved me, so I have loved you. Abide in my love.
verses.textLa: Sicut dilexit me Pater, et ego dilexi vos. Manete in dilectione mea.

verses.textEn: If you keep my precepts, you shall abide in my love, just as I also have kept my Father’s precepts and I abide in his love.
verses.textLa: Si præcepta mea servaveritis, manebitis in dilectione mea, sicut et ego Patris mei præcepta servavi, et maneo in eius dilectione.

verses.textEn: These things I have spoken to you, so that my joy may be in you, and your joy may be fulfilled.
verses.textLa: Hæc locutus sum vobis: ut gaudium meum in vobis sit, et gaudium vestrum impleatur.

verses.textEn: This is my precept: that you love one another, just as I have loved you.
verses.textLa: Hoc est præceptum meum ut diligatis invicem, sicut dilexi vos.

verses.textEn: No one has a greater love than this: that he lay down his life for his friends.
verses.textLa: Maiorem hac dilectionem nemo habet, ut animam suam ponat qui pro amicis suis.

verses.textEn: You are my friends, if you do what I instruct you.
verses.textLa: Vos amici mei estis, si feceritis quæ ego præcipio vobis.

verses.textEn: I will no longer call you servants, for the servant does not know what his Lord is doing. But I have called you friends, because everything whatsoever that I have heard from my Father, I have made known to you.
verses.textLa: Iam non dicam vos servos: quia servus nescit quid faciat dominus eius. Vos autem dixi amicos: quia omnia quæcumque audivi a Patre meo, nota feci vobis.

verses.textEn: You have not chosen me, but I have chosen you. And I have appointed you, so that you may go forth and bear fruit, and so that your fruit may last. Then whatever you have asked of the Father in my name, he shall give to you.
verses.textLa: Non vos me elegistis: sed ego elegi vos, et posui vos ut eatis, et fructum afferatis: et fructus vester maneat: ut quodcumque petieritis Patrem in nomine meo, det vobis.

verses.textEn: This I command you: that you love one another.
verses.textLa: Hæc mando vobis, ut diligatis invicem.

verses.textEn: If the world hates you, know that it has hated me before you.
verses.textLa: Si mundus vos odit: scitote quia me priorem vobis odio habuit.

verses.textEn: If you had been of the world, the world would love what is its own. Yet truly, you are not of the world, but I have chosen you out of the world; because of this, the world hates you.
verses.textLa: Si de mundo fuissetis: mundus quod suum erat diligeret: quia vero de mundo non estis, sed ego elegi vos de mundo, propterea odit vos mundus.

verses.textEn: Remember my saying that I told you: The servant is not greater than his Lord. If they have persecuted me, they will persecute you also. If they have kept my word, they will keep yours also.
verses.textLa: Mementote sermonis mei, quem ego dixi vobis: non est servus maior domino suo. Si me persecuti sunt, et vos persequentur: si sermonem meum servaverunt, et vestrum servabunt.

verses.textEn: But all these things they will do to you because of my name, for they do not know him who sent me.
verses.textLa: Sed hæc omnia facient vobis propter nomen meum: quia nesciunt eum, qui misit me.

verses.textEn: If I had not come and had not spoken to them, they would not have sin. But now they have no excuse for their sin.
verses.textLa: Si non venissem, et locutus fuissem eis, peccatum non haberent: nunc autem excusationem non habent de peccato suo.

verses.textEn: Whoever hates me, hates my Father also.
verses.textLa: Qui me odit: et Patrem meum odit.

verses.textEn: If I had not accomplished among them works that no other person has accomplished, they would not have sin. But now they have both seen me, and they have hated me and my Father.
verses.textLa: Si opera non fecissem in eis, quæ nemo alius fecit, peccatum non haberent: nunc autem et viderunt, et oderunt et me, et Patrem meum.

verses.textEn: But this is so that the word may be fulfilled which was written in their law: ‘For they hated me without cause.’
verses.textLa: Sed ut adimpleatur sermo, qui in lege eorum scriptus est: Quia odio habuerunt me gratis.

verses.textEn: But when the Advocate has arrived, whom I will send to you from the Father, the Spirit of truth who proceeds from the Father, he will offer testimony about me.
verses.textLa: Cum autem venerit Paraclitus, quem ego mittam vobis a Patre, Spiritum veritatis, qui a Patre procedit, ille testimonium perhibebit de me:

verses.textEn: And you shall offer testimony, because you are with me from the beginning.”
verses.textLa: et vos testimonium perhibebitis, quia ab initio mecum estis.

verses.textEn: “These things I have spoken to you, so that you would not stumble.
verses.textLa: Hæc locutus sum vobis, ut non scandalizemini.
verses.notes: Or, ‘would not be scandalized.’ The word ‘scandalized’ is becoming fairly obscure in English, and the word ‘scandal’ has a different meaning in secular usage than it does in religious usage, so stumble is perhaps a better choice.

verses.textEn: They will put you out of the synagogues. But the hour is coming when everyone who puts you to death will consider that he is offering an excellent service to God.
verses.textLa: Absque synagogis facient vos: sed venit hora, ut omnis, qui interficit vos, arbitretur obsequium se præstare Deo.

verses.textEn: And they will do these things to you because they have not known the Father, nor me.
verses.textLa: Et hæc facient vobis, quia non noverunt Patrem, neque me.

verses.textEn: But these things I have spoken to you, so that, when the hour for these things will have arrived, you may remember that I told you.
verses.textLa: Sed hæc locutus sum vobis: ut cum venerit hora eorum reminiscamini, quia ego dixi vobis.

verses.textEn: But I did not tell you these things from the beginning, because I was with you. And now I am going to him who sent me. And no one among you has asked me, ‘Where are you going?’
verses.textLa: Hæc autem vobis ab initio non dixi, quia vobiscum eram: Et nunc vado ad eum, qui misit me; et nemo ex vobis interrogat me, Quo vadis?

verses.textEn: But because I have spoken these things to you, sorrow has filled your heart.
verses.textLa: Sed quia hæc locutus sum vobis, tristitia implevit cor vestrum.

verses.textEn: But I tell you the truth: it is expedient for you that I am going. For if I do not go, the Advocate will not come to you. But when I will have gone away, I will send him to you.
verses.textLa: Sed ego veritatem dico vobis: expedit vobis ut ego vadam: si enim non abiero, Paraclitus non veniet ad vos: si autem abiero, mittam eum ad vos.

verses.textEn: And when he has arrived, he will argue against the world, about sin and about justice and about judgment:
verses.textLa: Et cum venerit ille, arguet mundum de peccato, et de iustitia, et de iudicio.

verses.textEn: about sin, indeed, because they have not believed in me;
verses.textLa: De peccato quidem: quia non crediderunt in me.

verses.textEn: about justice, truly, because I am going to the Father, and you will not see me any longer;
verses.textLa: De iustitia vero: quia ad Patrem vado: et iam non videbitis me:

verses.textEn: about judgment, then, because the prince of this world has already been judged.
verses.textLa: De iudicio autem: quia princeps huius mundi iam iudicatus est.

verses.textEn: I still have many things to say to you, but you are not able to bear them now.
verses.textLa: Adhuc multa habeo vobis dicere: sed non potestis portare modo.

verses.textEn: But when the Spirit of truth has arrived, he will teach the whole truth to you. For he will not be speaking from himself. Instead, whatever he will hear, he will speak. And he will announce to you the things that are to come.
verses.textLa: Cum autem venerit ille Spiritus veritatis, docebit vos omnem veritatem. Non enim loquetur a semetipso: sed quæcumque audiet loquetur, et quæ ventura sunt annunciabit vobis.

verses.textEn: He shall glorify me. For he will receive from what is mine, and he will announce it to you.
verses.textLa: Ille me clarificabit: quia de meo accipiet, et annunciabit vobis.

verses.textEn: All things whatsoever that the Father has are mine. For this reason, I said that he will receive from what is mine and that he will announce it to you.
verses.textLa: Omnia quæcumque habet Pater, mea sunt. Propterea dixi: quia de meo accipiet, et annunciabit vobis.

verses.textEn: A little while, and then you will not see me. And again a little while, and you will see me. For I am going to the Father.”
verses.textLa: Modicum, et iam non videbitis me: et iterum modicum, et videbitis me: quia vado ad Patrem.

verses.textEn: Then some of his disciples said to one another: “What is this, that he is saying to us: ‘A little while, and you will not see me,’ and ‘Again a little while, and you will see me,’ and, ‘For I am going to the Father?’ ”
verses.textLa: Dixerunt ergo ex discipulis eius ad invicem: Quid est hoc, quod dicit nobis: Modicum, et non videbitis me: et iterum modicum, et videbitis me, et quia vado ad Patrem?

verses.textEn: And they said: “What is this, that he is saying, ‘A little while?’ We do not understand what he is saying.”
verses.textLa: Dicebant ergo: Quid est hoc, quod dicit, Modicum? nescimus quid loquitur.

verses.textEn: But Jesus realized that they wanted to question him, and so he said to them: “Are you inquiring among yourselves about this, that I said: ‘A little while, and you will not see me, and again a little while, and you will see me?’
verses.textLa: Cognovit autem Iesus, quia volebant eum interrogare, et dixit eis: De hoc quæritis inter vos quia dixi, Modicum, et non videbitis me: et iterum modicum, et videbitis me.

verses.textEn: Amen, amen, I say to you, that you shall mourn and weep, but the world will rejoice. And you shall be greatly saddened, yet your sorrow shall be turned into joy.
verses.textLa: Amen, amen dico vobis: quia plorabitis, et flebitis vos, mundus autem gaudebit: vos autem contristabimini, sed tristitia vestra vertetur in gaudium.

verses.textEn: A woman, when she is giving birth, has sorrow, because her hour has arrived. But when she has given birth to the child, then she no longer remembers the difficulties, because of the joy: for a man has been born into the world.
verses.textLa: Mulier cum parit, tristitiam habet, quia venit hora eius: cum autem pepererit puerum, iam non meminit pressuræ propter gaudium: quia natus est homo in mundum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, you also, indeed, have sorrow now. But I will see you again, and your heart shall rejoice. And no one will take away your joy from you.
verses.textLa: Et vos igitur nunc quidem tristitiam habetis, iterum autem videbo vos, et gaudebit cor vestrum: et gaudium vestrum nemo tollet a vobis.

verses.textEn: And, in that day, you will not petition me for anything. Amen, amen, I say to you, if you ask the Father for anything in my name, he will give it to you.
verses.textLa: Et in illo die me non rogabitis quidquam. Amen, amen dico vobis: siquid petieritis Patrem in nomine meo, dabit vobis.

verses.textEn: Until now, you have not requested anything in my name. Ask, and you shall receive, so that your joy may be full.
verses.textLa: Usque modo non petistis quidquam in nomine meo: Petite, et accipietis, ut gaudium vestrum sit plenum.

verses.textEn: I have spoken these things to you in proverbs. The hour is coming when I will no longer speak to you in proverbs; instead, I will announce to you plainly from the Father.
verses.textLa: Hæc in proverbiis locutus sum vobis. Venit hora cum iam non in proverbiis loquar vobis, sed palam de Patre annunciabo vobis.

verses.textEn: In that day, you shall ask in my name, and I do not say to you that I will ask the Father for you.
verses.textLa: In illo die in nomine meo petetis: et non dico vobis quia ego rogabo Patrem de vobis:

verses.textEn: For the Father himself loves you, because you have loved me, and because you have believed that I went forth from God.
verses.textLa: Ipse enim Pater amat vos, quia vos me amastis, et credidistis, quia ego a Deo exivi.

verses.textEn: I went forth from the Father, and I have come into the world. Next I am leaving the world, and I am going to the Father.”
verses.textLa: Exivi a Patre, et veni in mundum: iterum relinquo mundum, et vado ad Patrem.

verses.textEn: His disciples said to him: “Behold, now you are speaking plainly and not reciting a proverb.
verses.textLa: Dicunt ei discipuli eius: Ecce nunc palam loqueris, et proverbium nullum dicis.

verses.textEn: Now we know that you know all things, and that you have no need for anyone to question you. By this, we believe that you went forth from God.”
verses.textLa: Nunc scimus quia scis omnia, et non opus est tibi ut quis te interroget: in hoc credimus quia a Deo existi.

verses.textEn: Jesus answered them: “Do you believe now?
verses.textLa: Respondit eis Iesus: Modo creditis?

verses.textEn: Behold, the hour is coming, and it has now arrived, when you will be scattered, each one on his own, and you will leave me behind, alone. And yet I am not alone, for the Father is with me.
verses.textLa: Ecce venit hora, et iam venit, ut dispergamini unusquisque in propria, et me solum relinquatis: et non sum solus, quia Pater mecum est.

verses.textEn: These things I have spoken to you, so that you may have peace in me. In the world, you will have difficulties. But have confidence: I have overcome the world.”
verses.textLa: Hæc locutus sum vobis, ut in me pacem habeatis. In mundo pressuram habebitis: sed confidite, ego vici mundum.

verses.textEn: Jesus said these things, and then, lifting up his eyes toward heaven, he said: “Father, the hour has arrived: glorify your Son, so that your Son may glorify you,
verses.textLa: Hæc locutus est Iesus: et sublevatis oculis in cælum, dixit: Pater venit hora, clarifica Filium tuum, ut Filius tuus clarificet te:
verses.notes: Here and in subsequent verses, the word ‘clarificet’ is translated as ‘glorify.’ There is perhaps no better word in his context, but the word in Latin is a bit different than glorify. It has more of a sense of making something well-known, and is somewhat less abstract than glorify.

verses.textEn: just as you have given authority over all flesh to him, so that he may give eternal life to all those whom you have given to him.
verses.textLa: Sicut dedisti ei potestatem omnis carnis, ut omne, quod dedisti ei, det eis vitam æternam.

verses.textEn: And this is eternal life: that they may know you, the only true God, and Jesus Christ, whom you have sent.
verses.textLa: Hæc est autem vita æterna: Ut cognoscant te, solum Deum verum, et quem misisti Iesum Christum.

verses.textEn: I have glorified you on earth. I have completed the work that you gave me to accomplish.
verses.textLa: Ego te clarificavi super terram: opus consummavi, quod dedisti mihi ut faciam:

verses.textEn: And now Father, glorify me within yourself, with the glory that I had with you before the world ever was.
verses.textLa: et nunc clarifica me tu Pater apud temetipsum, claritate, quam habui prius, quam mundus esset, apud te.

verses.textEn: I have manifested your name to the men whom you have given to me from the world. They were yours, and you gave them to me. And they have kept your word.
verses.textLa: Manifestavi nomen tuum hominibus, quos dedisti mihi de mundo: Tui erant, et mihi eos dedisti: et sermonem tuum servaverunt.

verses.textEn: Now they realize that all the things that you have given me are from you.
verses.textLa: Nunc cognoverunt quia omnia, quæ dedisti mihi, abs te sunt:

verses.textEn: For I have given them the words that you gave to me. And they have accepted these words, and they have truly understood that I went forth from you, and they have believed that you sent me.
verses.textLa: quia verba, quæ dedisti mihi, dedi eis: et ipsi acceperunt, et cognoverunt vere quia a te exivi, et crediderunt quia tu me misisti.

verses.textEn: I pray for them. I do not pray for the world, but for those whom you have given to me. For they are yours.
verses.textLa: Ego pro eis rogo: Non pro mundo rogo, sed pro his, quos dedisti mihi: quia tui sunt:

verses.textEn: And all that is mine is yours, and all that is yours is mine, and I am glorified in this.
verses.textLa: et mea omnia tua sunt, et tua mea sunt: et clarificatus sum in eis:

verses.textEn: And though I am not in the world, these are in the world, and I am coming to you. Father most holy, preserve them in your name, those whom you have given to me, so that they may be one, even as we are one.
verses.textLa: Et iam non sum in mundo, et hi in mundo sunt, et ego ad te venio. Pater sancte, serva eos in nomine tuo, quos dedisti mihi: ut sint unum, sicut et nos.

verses.textEn: While I was with them, I preserved them in your name. I have guarded those whom you have given to me, and not one of them is lost, except the son of perdition, so that the Scripture may be fulfilled.
verses.textLa: Cum essem cum eis, ego servabam eos in nomine tuo. Quos dedisti mihi, custodivi: et nemo ex eis periit, nisi filius perditionis, ut Scriptura impleatur.

verses.textEn: And now I am coming to you. But I am speaking these things in the world, so that they may have the fullness of my joy within themselves.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem ad te venio: et hæc loquor in mundo, ut habeant gaudium meum impletum in semetipsis.

verses.textEn: I have given them your word, and the world has hated them. For they are not of the world, just as I, too, am not of the world.
verses.textLa: Ego dedi eis sermonem tuum, et mundus eos odio habuit, quia non sunt de mundo, sicut et ego non sum de mundo.

verses.textEn: I am not praying that you would take them out of the world, but that you would preserve them from evil.
verses.textLa: Non rogo ut tollas eos de mundo, sed ut serves eos a malo.

verses.textEn: They are not of the world, just as I also am not of the world.
verses.textLa: De mundo non sunt, sicut et ego non sum de mundo.

verses.textEn: Sanctify them in truth. Your word is truth.
verses.textLa: Sanctifica eos in veritate. Sermo tuus veritas est.

verses.textEn: Just as you have sent me into the world, I also have sent them into the world.
verses.textLa: Sicut tu me misisti in mundum, et ego misi eos in mundum.

verses.textEn: And it is for them that I sanctify myself, so that they, too, may be sanctified in truth.
verses.textLa: Et pro eis ego sanctifico meipsum: ut sint et ipsi sanctificati in veritate.

verses.textEn: But I am not praying for them only, but also for those who through their word shall believe in me.
verses.textLa: Non pro eis autem rogo tantum, sed et pro eis, qui credituri sunt per verbum eorum in me:

verses.textEn: So may they all be one. Just as you, Father, are in me, and I am in you, so also may they be one in us: so that the world may believe that you have sent me.
verses.textLa: ut omnes unum sint, sicut tu Pater in me, et ego in te, ut et ipsi in nobis unum sint: ut credat mundus, quia tu me misisti.

verses.textEn: And the glory that you have given to me, I have given to them, so that they may be one, just as we also are one.
verses.textLa: Et ego claritatem, quam dedisti mihi, dedi eis: ut sint unum, sicut et nos unum sumus.

verses.textEn: I am in them, and you are in me. So may they be perfected as one. And may the world know that you have sent me and that you have loved them, just as you have also loved me.
verses.textLa: Ego in eis, et tu in me: ut sint consummati in unum: et cognoscat mundus quia tu me misisti, et dilexisti eos, sicut et me dilexisti.

verses.textEn: Father, I will that where I am, those whom you have given to me may also be with me, so that they may see my glory which you have given to me. For you loved me before the founding of the world.
verses.textLa: Pater, quos dedisti mihi, volo ut ubi sum ego, et illi sint mecum: ut videant claritatem meam, quam dedisti mihi: quia dilexisti me ante constitutionem mundi.

verses.textEn: Father most just, the world has not known you. But I have known you. And these have known that you sent me.
verses.textLa: Pater iuste, mundus te non cognovit. Ego autem te cognovi: et hi cognoverunt, quia tu me misisti.

verses.textEn: And I have made known your name to them, and I will make it known, so that the love in which you have loved me may be in them, and so that I may be in them.”
verses.textLa: Et notum feci eis nomen tuum, et notum faciam: ut dilectio, qua dilexisti me, in ipsis sit, et ego in ipsis.

verses.textEn: When Jesus had said these things, he departed with his disciples across the Torrent of Kidron, where there was a garden, into which he entered with his disciples.
verses.textLa: Hæc cum dixisset Iesus, egressus est cum discipulis suis trans Torrentem Cedron, ubi erat hortus, in quem introivit ipse, et discipuli eius.

verses.textEn: But Judas, who betrayed him, also knew the place, for Jesus had frequently met with his disciples there.
verses.textLa: Sciebat autem et Iudas, qui tradebat eum, locum: quia frequenter Iesus convenerat illuc cum discipulis suis.

verses.textEn: Then Judas, when he had received a cohort from both the high priests and the attendants of the Pharisees, approached the place with lanterns and torches and weapons.
verses.textLa: Iudas ergo cum accepisset cohortem, et a Pontificibus, et Pharisæis ministros, venit illuc cum laternis, et facibus, et armis.

verses.textEn: And so Jesus, knowing all that was about to happen to him, advanced and said to them, “Who are you seeking?”
verses.textLa: Iesus itaque sciens omnia, quæ ventura erant super eum, processit, et dixit eis: Quem quæritis?
verses.notes: I realize that using Who instead of Whom is grammatically incorrect, but using Whom is awkward sounding and it is not the way that people speak in conversation.

verses.textEn: They answered him, “Jesus the Nazarene.” Jesus said to them, “I am he.” Now Judas, who betrayed him, was also standing with them.
verses.textLa: Responderunt ei: Iesum Nazarenum. Dicit eis Iesus: Ego sum. Stabat autem et Iudas, qui tradebat eum, cum ipsis.

verses.textEn: Then, when he said to them, “I am he,” they moved back and fell to the ground.
verses.textLa: Ut ergo dixit eis: Ego sum: abierunt retrorsum, et ceciderunt in terram.

verses.textEn: Then again he questioned them: “Who are you seeking?” And they said, “Jesus the Nazarene.”
verses.textLa: Iterum ergo interrogavit eos: Quem quæritis? Illi autem dixerunt: Iesum Nazarenum.

verses.textEn: Jesus responded: “I told you that I am he. Therefore, if you are seeking me, permit these others to go away.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus: Dixi vobis, quia ego sum: si ergo me quæritis, sinite hos abire.

verses.textEn: This was so that the word might be fulfilled, which he said, “Of those whom you have given to me, I have not lost any of them.”
verses.textLa: Ut impleretur sermo, quem dixit: Quia quos dedisti mihi, non perdidi ex eis quemquam.

verses.textEn: Then Simon Peter, having a sword, drew it, and he struck the servant of the high priest, and he cut off his right ear. Now the name of the servant was Malchus.
verses.textLa: Simon ergo Petrus habens gladium eduxit eum: et percussit pontificis servum: et abscidit auriculam eius dexteram. Erat autem nomen servo Malchus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Jesus said to Peter: “Set your sword into the scabbard. Should I not drink the chalice which my Father has given to me?”
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo Iesus Petro: Mitte gladium tuum in vaginam. Calicem, quem dedit mihi Pater, non bibam illum?

verses.textEn: Then the cohort, and the tribune, and the attendants of the Jews apprehended Jesus and bound him.
verses.textLa: Cohors ergo, et tribunus, et ministri Iudæorum comprehenderunt Iesum, et ligaverunt eum:

verses.textEn: And they led him away, first to Annas, for he was the father-in-law of Caiaphas, who was the high priest that year.
verses.textLa: Et adduxerunt eum ad Annam primum, erat enim socer Caiphæ, qui erat pontifex anni illius.

verses.textEn: Now Caiaphas was the one who had given counsel to the Jews that it was expedient for one man to die for the people.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Caiphas, qui consilium dederat Iudæis: Quia expedit, unum hominem mori pro populo.

verses.textEn: And Simon Peter was following Jesus with another disciple. And that disciple was known to the high priest, and so he entered with Jesus into the court of the high priest.
verses.textLa: Sequebatur autem Iesum Simon Petrus, et alius discipulus. Discipulus autem ille erat notus pontifici, et introivit cum Iesu in atrium pontificis.

verses.textEn: But Peter was standing outside at the entrance. Therefore, the other disciple, who was known to the high priest, went out and spoke to the woman who was the doorkeeper, and he led in Peter.
verses.textLa: Petrus autem stabat ad ostium foris. Exivit ergo discipulus alius, qui erat notus pontifici, et dixit ostiariæ: et introduxit Petrum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the woman servant keeping the door said to Peter, “Are you not also among the disciples of this man?” He said, “I am not.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ergo Petro ancilla ostiaria: Numquid et tu ex discipulis es hominis istius? Dicit ille: Non sum.

verses.textEn: Now the servants and attendants were standing before burning coals, for it was cold, and they were warming themselves. And Peter was standing with them also, warming himself.
verses.textLa: Stabant autem servi, et ministri ad prunas: quia frigus erat, et calefaciebant se: erat autem cum eis et Petrus stans, et calefaciens se.

verses.textEn: Then the high priest questioned Jesus about his disciples and about his doctrine.
verses.textLa: Pontifex ergo interrogavit Iesum de discipulis suis, et de doctrina eius.

verses.textEn: Jesus responded to him: “I have spoken openly to the world. I have always taught in the synagogue and in the temple, where all the Jews meet. And I have said nothing in secret.
verses.textLa: Respondit ei Iesus: Ego palam locutus sum mundo: ego semper docui in synagoga, et in templo, quo omnes Iudæi conveniunt: et in occulto locutus sum nihil.

verses.textEn: Why do you question me? Question those who heard what I said to them. Behold, they know these things that I have said.”
verses.textLa: Quid me interrogas? Interroga eos, qui audierunt quid locutus sim ipsis: ecce hi sciunt quæ dixerim ego.

verses.textEn: Then, when he had said this, one of the attendants standing nearby struck Jesus, saying: “Is this the way you answer the high priest?”
verses.textLa: Hæc autem cum dixisset, unus assistens ministrorum dedit alapam Iesu, dicens: Sic respondes pontifici?

verses.textEn: Jesus answered him: “If I have spoken wrongly, offer testimony about the wrong. But if I have spoken correctly, then why do you strike me?”
verses.textLa: Respondit ei Iesus: Si male locutus sum, testimonium perhibe de malo: si autem bene, quid me cædis?

verses.textEn: And Annas sent him bound to Caiaphas, the high priest.
verses.textLa: Et misit eum Annas ligatum ad Caipham pontificem.

verses.textEn: Now Simon Peter was standing and warming himself. Then they said to him, “Are you not also one of his disciples?” He denied it and said, “I am not.”
verses.textLa: Erat autem Simon Petrus stans, et calefaciens se. Dixerunt ergo ei: Numquid et tu ex discipulis eius es? Negavit ille, et dixit: Non sum.

verses.textEn: One of the servants of the high priest (a relative of him whose ear Peter had cut off) said to him, “Did I not see you in the garden with him?”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei unus ex servis pontificis, cognatus eius, cuius abscidit Petrus auriculam: Nonne ego te vidi in horto cum illo?

verses.textEn: Therefore, again, Peter denied it. And immediately the rooster crowed.
verses.textLa: Iterum ergo negavit Petrus: et statim gallus cantavit.

verses.textEn: Then they led Jesus from Caiaphas into the praetorium. Now it was morning, and so they did not enter into the praetorium, so that they would not be defiled, but might eat the Passover.
verses.textLa: Adducunt ergo Iesum a Caipha in prætorium. Erat autem mane: et ipsi non introierunt in prætorium, ut non contaminarentur, sed ut manducarent Pascha.
verses.notes: The Last Supper occurred a day earlier than most Jews celebrated the Passover supper, so that Jesus could both celebrate the Passover and be the Passover Lamb on the Cross. This was arranged by the Providence of God and permitted by a tradition of the Jews for those from Galilee.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Pilate went outside to them, and he said, “What accusation are you bringing against this man?”
verses.textLa: Exivit ergo Pilatus ad eos foras, et dixit: Quam accusationem affertis adversus hominem hunc?

verses.textEn: They responded and said to him, “If he were not an evil-doer, we would not have handed him over to you.”
verses.textLa: Responderunt, et dixerunt ei: Si non esset hic malefactor, non tibi tradidissemus eum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Pilate said to them, “Take him yourselves and judge him according to your own law.” Then the Jews said to him, “It is not lawful for us to execute anyone.”
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo eis Pilatus: Accipite eum vos, et secundum legem vestram iudicate eum. Dixerunt ergo ei Iudæi: Nobis non licet interficere quemquam.

verses.textEn: This was so that the word of Jesus would be fulfilled, which he spoke signifying what kind of death he would die.
verses.textLa: Ut sermo Iesu impleretur, quem dixit, significans qua morte esset moriturus.

verses.textEn: Then Pilate entered the praetorium again, and he called Jesus and said to him, “You are the king of the Jews?”
verses.textLa: Introivit ergo iterum in prætorium Pilatus, et vocavit Iesum, et dixit ei: Tu es rex Iudæorum?

verses.textEn: Jesus responded, “Are you saying this of yourself, or have others spoken to you about me?”
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus: A temetipso hoc dicis, an alii dixerunt tibi de me?

verses.textEn: Pilate responded: “Am I a Jew? Your own nation and the high priests have handed you over to me. What have you done?”
verses.textLa: Respondit Pilatus: Numquid ego Iudæus sum? Gens tua, et pontifices tradiderunt te mihi: quid fecisti?

verses.textEn: Jesus responded: “My kingdom is not of this world. If my kingdom were of this world, my ministers would certainly strive so that I would not be handed over to the Jews. But my kingdom is not now from here.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus: Regnum meum non est de hoc mundo. Si ex hoc mundo esset regnum meum, ministri mei utique decertarent ut non traderer Iudæis: nunc autem regnum meum non est hinc.

verses.textEn: And so Pilate said to him, “You are a king, then?” Jesus answered, “You are saying that I am a king. For this I was born, and for this I came into the world: so that I may offer testimony to the truth. Everyone who is of the truth hears my voice.”
verses.textLa: Dixit itaque ei Pilatus: Ergo rex es tu? Respondit Iesus: Tu dicis quia rex sum ego. Ego in hoc natus sum, et ad hoc veni in mundum, ut testimonium perhibeam veritati: omnis, qui est ex veritate, audit vocem meam.

verses.textEn: Pilate said to him, “What is truth?” And when he had said this, he went out again to the Jews, and he said to them, “I find no case against him.
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Pilatus: Quid est veritas? Et cum hoc dixisset, iterum exivit ad Iudæos, et dicit eis: Ego nullam invenio in eo causam.

verses.textEn: But you have a custom, that I should release someone to you at the Passover. Therefore, do you want me to release to you the king of the Jews?”
verses.textLa: Est autem consuetudo vobis ut unum dimittam vobis in Pascha: vultis ergo dimittam vobis regem Iudæorum?

verses.textEn: Then they all cried out repeatedly, saying: “Not this one, but Barabbas.” Now Barabbas was a robber.
verses.textLa: Clamaverunt ergo rursum omnes, dicentes: Non hunc, sed Barabbam. Erat autem Barabbas latro.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Pilate then took Jesus into custody and scourged him.
verses.textLa: Tunc ergo apprehendit Pilatus Iesum, et flagellavit.

verses.textEn: And the soldiers, plaiting a crown of thorns, imposed it on his head. And they put a purple garment around him.
verses.textLa: Et milites plectentes coronam de spinis, imposuerunt capiti eius: et veste purpurea circumdederunt eum.

verses.textEn: And they were approaching him and saying, “Hail, king of the Jews!” And they struck him repeatedly.
verses.textLa: Et veniebant ad eum, et dicebant: Ave, rex Iudæorum: et dabant ei alapas.
verses.notes: The expression ‘dabant alapas’ has the verb in the imperative tense, so the translation of ‘repeatedly’ is justified. More literally (and more awkwardly) it says ‘they were giving him blows.’

verses.textEn: Then Pilate went outside again, and he said to them: “Behold, I am bringing him out to you, so that you may realize that I find no case against him.”
verses.textLa: Exivit ergo iterum Pilatus foras, et dicit eis: Ecce adduco vobis eum foras, ut cognoscatis quia nullam invenio in eo causam.

verses.textEn: (Then Jesus went out, bearing the crown of thorns and the purple garment.) And he said to them, “Behold the man.”
verses.textLa: (Exivit ergo Iesus portans coronam spineam, et purpureum vestimentum:) Et dicit eis: Ecce homo.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when the high priests and the attendants had seen him, they cried out, saying: “Crucify him! Crucify him!” Pilate said to them: “Take him yourselves and crucify him. For I find no case against him.”
verses.textLa: Cum ergo vidissent eum Pontifices, et ministri, clamabant, dicentes: Crucifige, crucifige eum. Dicit eis Pilatus: Accipite eum vos, et crucifigite: ego enim non invenio in eo causam.

verses.textEn: The Jews answered him, “We have a law, and according to the law, he ought to die, for he has made himself the Son of God.”
verses.textLa: Responderunt ei Iudæi: Nos legem habemus, et secundum legem debet mori, quia Filium Dei se fecit.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when Pilate had heard this word, he was more fearful.
verses.textLa: Cum ergo audisset Pilatus hunc sermonem, magis timuit.

verses.textEn: And he entered into the praetorium again. And he said to Jesus. “Where are you from?” But Jesus gave him no response.
verses.textLa: Et ingressus est prætorium iterum: et dixit ad Iesum: Unde es tu? Iesus autem responsum non dedit ei.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Pilate said to him: “Will you not speak to me? Do you not know that I have authority to crucify you, and I have authority to release you?”
verses.textLa: Dicit ergo ei Pilatus: Mihi non loqueris? Nescis quia potestatem habeo crucifigere te, et potestatem habeo dimittere te?

verses.textEn: Jesus responded, “You would not have any authority over me, unless it were given to you from above. For this reason, he who has handed me over to you has the greater sin.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Iesus: Non haberes potestatem adversum me ullam, nisi tibi datum esset desuper. Propterea qui me tradidit tibi, maius peccatum habet.

verses.textEn: And from then on, Pilate was seeking to release him. But the Jews were crying out, saying: “If you release this man, you are no friend of Caesar. For anyone who makes himself a king contradicts Caesar.”
verses.textLa: Et exinde quærebat Pilatus dimittere eum. Iudæi autem clamabant dicentes: Si hunc dimittis, non es amicus Cæsaris. Omnis enim, qui se regem facit, contradicit Cæsari.

verses.textEn: Now when Pilate had heard these words, he brought Jesus outside, and he sat down in the seat of judgment, in a place which is called the Pavement, but in Hebrew, it is called the Elevation.
verses.textLa: Pilatus autem cum audisset hos sermones, adduxit foras Iesum: et sedit pro tribunali, in loco, qui dicitur Lithostrotos, Hebraice autem Gabbatha.

verses.textEn: Now it was the preparation day of the Passover, about the sixth hour. And he said to the Jews, “Behold your king.”
verses.textLa: Erat autem parasceve Paschæ, hora quasi sexta, et dicit Iudæis: Ecce rex vester.

verses.textEn: But they were crying out: “Take him away! Take him away! Crucify him!” Pilate said to them, “Shall I crucify your king?” The high priests responded, “We have no king except Caesar.”
verses.textLa: Illi autem clamabant: Tolle, tolle, crucifige eum. Dicit eis Pilatus: Regem vestrum crucifigam? Responderunt Pontifices: Non habemus Regem, nisi Cæsarem.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he then handed him over to them to be crucified. And they took Jesus and led him away.
verses.textLa: Tunc ergo tradidit eis illum ut crucifigeretur. Susceperunt autem Iesum, et eduxerunt.

verses.textEn: And carrying his own cross, he went forth to the place which is called Calvary, but in Hebrew it is called the Place of the Skull.
verses.textLa: Et baiulans sibi crucem exivit in eum, qui dicitur Calvariæ, locum, Hebraice autem Golgotha:

verses.textEn: There they crucified him, and with him two others, one on each side, with Jesus in the middle.
verses.textLa: ubi crucifixerunt eum, et cum eo alios duos hinc, et hinc, medium autem Iesum.

verses.textEn: Then Pilate also wrote a title, and he set it above the cross. And it was written: JESUS THE NAZARENE, KING OF THE JEWS.
verses.textLa: Scripsit autem et titulum Pilatus: et posuit super crucem. Erat autem scriptum: Iesus Nazarenus, Rex Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, many of the Jews read this title, for the place where Jesus was crucified was close to the city. And it was written in Hebrew, in Greek, and in Latin.
verses.textLa: Hunc ergo titulum multi Iudæorum legerunt: quia prope civitatem erat locus, ubi crucifixus est Iesus: Et erat scriptum Hebraice, Græce, et Latine.

verses.textEn: Then the high priests of the Jews said to Pilate: Do not write, ‘King of the Jews,’ but that he said, ‘I am King of the Jews.’
verses.textLa: Dicebant ergo Pilato Pontifices Iudæorum: Noli scribere, Rex Iudæorum: sed quia ipse dixit: Rex sum Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: Pilate responded, “What I have written, I have written.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Pilatus: Quod scripsi, scripsi.
verses.notes: Pilate was most likely speaking in Latin when he said these words. These words show a manner of thought and expression found in ancient Roman culture and society. It is also a very natural expression in Latin.

verses.textEn: Then the soldiers, when they had crucified him, took his garments, and they made four parts, one part to each soldier, and the tunic. But the tunic was seamless, woven from above throughout the whole.
verses.textLa: Milites ergo cum crucifixissent eum, acceperunt vestimenta eius, (et fecerunt quattuor partes: unicuique militi partem) et tunicam. Erat autem tunica inconsutilis, desuper contexta per totum.

verses.textEn: Then they said to one another, “Let us not cut it, but instead let us cast lots over it, to see whose it will be.” This was so that the Scripture would be fulfilled, saying: “They have distributed my garments among themselves, and for my vesture they have cast lots.” And indeed, the soldiers did these things.
verses.textLa: Dixerunt ergo ad invicem: Non scindamus eam, sed sortiamur de illa cuius sit. Ut Scriptura impleretur, dicens: Partiti sunt vestimenta mea sibi: et in vestem meam miserunt sortem. Et milites quidem hæc fecerunt.

verses.textEn: And standing beside the cross of Jesus were his mother, and his mother’s sister, and Mary of Cleophas, and Mary Magdalene.
verses.textLa: Stabant autem iuxta crucem Iesu mater eius, et soror matris eius, Maria Cleophæ, et Maria Magdalene.
verses.notes: According to Blessed Anne Catherine Emmerich, Mary Cleophas was the daughter of Cleophas and Maria Heli (the Virgin Mary’s older sister). So the sister of Christ’s mother, and the woman named Mary Cleophas are two different persons.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when Jesus had seen his mother and the disciple whom he loved standing near, he said to his mother, “Woman, behold your son.”
verses.textLa: Cum vidisset ergo Iesus matrem, et discipulum stantem, quem diligebat, dicit matri suæ: Mulier, ecce filius tuus.

verses.textEn: Next, he said to the disciple, “Behold your mother.” And from that hour, the disciple accepted her as his own.
verses.textLa: Deinde dicit discipulo: Ecce mater tua. Et ex illa hora accepit eam discipulus in sua.

verses.textEn: After this, Jesus knew that all had been accomplished, so in order that the Scripture might be completed, he said, “I thirst.”
verses.textLa: Postea sciens Iesus quia omnia consummata sunt, ut consummaretur Scriptura, dixit: Sitio.

verses.textEn: And there was a container placed there, full of vinegar. Then, placing a sponge full of vinegar around hyssop, they brought it to his mouth.
verses.textLa: Vas ergo erat positum aceto plenum. Illi autem spongiam plenam aceto, hyssopo circumponentes, obtulerunt ori eius.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus, when he had received the vinegar, said: “It is consummated.” And bowing down his head, he surrendered his spirit.
verses.textLa: Cum ergo accepisset Iesus acetum, dixit: Consummatum est. Et inclinato capite tradidit spiritum.

verses.textEn: Then the Jews, because it was the preparation day, so that the bodies would not remain upon the cross on the Sabbath (for that Sabbath was a great day), they petitioned Pilate in order that their legs might be broken, and they might be taken away.
verses.textLa: Iudæi ergo, (quoniam Parasceve erat) ut non remanerent in cruce corpora Sabbato, (erat enim magnus dies ille Sabbati) rogaverunt Pilatum ut frangerentur eorum crura, et tollerentur.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the soldiers approached, and, indeed, they broke the legs of the first one, and of the other who was crucified with him.
verses.textLa: Venerunt ergo milites: et primi quidem fregerunt crura, et alterius, qui crucifixus est cum eo.

verses.textEn: But after they had approached Jesus, when they saw that he was already dead, they did not break his legs.
verses.textLa: Ad Iesum autem cum venissent, ut viderunt eum iam mortuum, non fregerunt eius crura,

verses.textEn: Instead, one of the soldiers opened his side with a lance, and immediately there went out blood and water.
verses.textLa: sed unus militum lancea latus eius aperuit, et continuo exivit sanguis, et aqua.

verses.textEn: And he who saw this has offered testimony, and his testimony is true. And he knows that he speaks the truth, so that you also may believe.
verses.textLa: Et qui vidit, testimonium perhibuit: et verum est testimonium eius. Et ille scit quia vera dicit: ut et vos credatis.

verses.textEn: For these things happened so that the Scripture would be fulfilled: “You shall not break a bone of him.”
verses.textLa: Facta sunt enim hæc ut Scriptura impleretur: Os non comminuetis ex eo.

verses.textEn: And again, another Scripture says: “They shall look upon him, whom they have pierced.”
verses.textLa: Et iterum alia Scriptura dicit: Videbunt in quem transfixerunt.

verses.textEn: Then, after these things, Joseph from Arimathea, (because he was a disciple of Jesus, but a secret one for fear of the Jews) petitioned Pilate so that he might take away the body of Jesus. And Pilate gave permission. Therefore, he went and took away the body of Jesus.
verses.textLa: Post hæc autem rogavit Pilatum Ioseph ab Arimathæa, (eo quod esset discipulus Iesu, occultus autem propter metum Iudæorum) ut tolleret corpus Iesu. Et permisit Pilatus. Venit ergo, et tulit corpus Iesu.

verses.textEn: Now Nicodemus also arrived, (who had gone to Jesus at first by night) bringing a mixture of myrrh and aloe, weighing about seventy pounds.
verses.textLa: Venit autem et Nicodemus, qui venerat ad Iesum nocte primum, ferens mixturam myrrhæ, et aloes, quasi libras centum.
verses.notes: The libra was a weight of one Roman pound, but this is substantially less than what is called a pound today. Thus 100 libras is not 100 modern pounds, but about 71.2 pounds or about 32.3 kilograms.

verses.textEn: Therefore, they took the body of Jesus, and they bound it with linen cloths and the aromatic spices, just as it is the manner of the Jews to bury.
verses.textLa: Acceperunt ergo corpus Iesu, et ligaverunt illud linteis cum aromatibus, sicut mos est Iudæis sepelire.

verses.textEn: Now in the place where he was crucified there was a garden, and in the garden there was a new tomb, in which no one had yet been laid.
verses.textLa: Erat autem in loco, ubi crucifixus est, hortus: et in horto monumentum novum, in quo nondum quisquam positus erat.

verses.textEn: Therefore, because of the preparation day of the Jews, since the tomb was nearby, they placed Jesus there.
verses.textLa: Ibi ergo propter Parasceven Iudæorum, quia iuxta erat monumentum, posuerunt Iesum.

verses.textEn: Then on the first Sabbath, Mary Magdalene went to the tomb early, while it was still dark, and she saw that the stone had been rolled away from the tomb.
verses.textLa: Una autem Sabbati, Maria Magdalene venit mane, cum adhuc tenebræ essent, ad monumentum: et vidit lapidem sublatum a monumento.
verses.notes: As with the other Gospels, John points out that this Sunday was the first Christian Sabbath. The phrase ‘una sabbati’ does not mean the first day of the week, but the first Sabbath.

verses.textEn: Therefore, she ran and went to Simon Peter, and to the other disciple, whom Jesus loved, and she said to them, “They have taken the Lord away from the tomb, and we do not know where they have laid him.”
verses.textLa: Cucurrit ergo, et venit ad Simonem Petrum, et ad alium discipulum, quem amabat Iesus, et dicit illis: Tulerunt Dominum de monumento, et nescimus ubi posuerunt eum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Peter departed with the other disciple, and they went to the tomb.
verses.textLa: Exiit ergo Petrus, et ille alius discipulus, et venerunt ad monumentum.

verses.textEn: Now they both ran together, but the other disciple ran more quickly, ahead of Peter, and so he arrived at the tomb first.
verses.textLa: Currebant autem duo simul, et ille alius discipulus præcucurrit citius Petro, et venit primus ad monumentum.

verses.textEn: And when he bowed down, he saw the linen cloths lying there, but he did not yet enter.
verses.textLa: Et cum se inclinasset, vidit posita linteamina, non tamen introivit.

verses.textEn: Then Simon Peter arrived, following him, and he entered the tomb, and he saw the linen cloths lying there,
verses.textLa: Venit ergo Simon Petrus sequens eum, et introivit in monumentum, et vidit linteamina posita,

verses.textEn: and the separate cloth which had been over his head, not placed with the linen cloths, but in a separate place, wrapped up by itself.
verses.textLa: et sudarium, quod fuerat super caput eius, non cum linteaminibus positum, sed separatim involutum in unum locum.

verses.textEn: Then the other disciple, who had arrived first at the tomb, also entered. And he saw and believed.
verses.textLa: Tunc ergo introivit et ille discipulus, qui venerat primus ad monumentum: et vidit, et credidit:

verses.textEn: For as yet they did not understand the Scripture, that it was necessary for him to rise again from the dead.
verses.textLa: nondum enim sciebant Scripturam, quia oportebat eum a mortuis resurgere.

verses.textEn: Then the disciples went away again, each by himself.
verses.textLa: Abierunt ergo iterum discipuli ad semetipsos.

verses.textEn: But Mary was standing outside the tomb, weeping. Then, while she was weeping, she bowed down and gazed into the tomb.
verses.textLa: Maria autem stabat ad monumentum foris, plorans: Dum ergo fleret, inclinavit se, et prospexit in monumentum:

verses.textEn: And she saw two Angels in white, sitting where the body of Jesus had been placed, one at the head, and one at the feet.
verses.textLa: et vidit duos Angelos in albis, sedentes, unum ad caput, et unum ad pedes, ubi positum fuerat corpus Iesu.

verses.textEn: They said to her, “Woman, why are you weeping?” She said to them, “Because they have taken away my Lord, and I do not know where they have placed him.”
verses.textLa: Dicunt ei illi: Mulier, quid ploras? Dicit eis: Quia tulerunt Dominum meum: et nescio ubi posuerunt eum.

verses.textEn: When she had said this, she turned around and saw Jesus standing there, but she did not know that it was Jesus.
verses.textLa: Hæc cum dixisset, conversa est retrorsum, et vidit Iesum stantem: et non sciebat quia Iesus est.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to her: “Woman, why are you weeping? Who are you seeking?” Considering that it was the gardener, she said to him, “Sir, if you have moved him, tell me where you have placed him, and I will take him away.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Iesus: Mulier, quid ploras? Quem quæris? Illa existimans quia hortulanus esset, dicit ei: Domine, si tu sustulisti eum, dicito mihi ubi posuisti eum: et ego eum tollam.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to her, “Mary!” And turning, she said to him, “Rabboni!” (which means, Teacher).
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Iesus: Maria. Conversa illa, dicit ei: Rabboni (quod dicitur Magister.)

verses.textEn: Jesus said to her: “Do not touch me. For I have not yet ascended to my Father. But go to my brothers and tell them: ‘I am ascending to my Father and to your Father, to my God and to your God.’ ”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Iesus: Noli me tangere, nondum enim ascendi ad Patrem meum: vade autem ad fratres meos, et dic eis: Ascendo ad Patrem meum, et Patrem vestrum, Deum meum, et Deum vestrum.

verses.textEn: Mary Magdalene went, announcing to the disciples, “I have seen the Lord, and these are the things that he said to me.”
verses.textLa: Venit Maria Magdalene annuncians discipulis: Quia vidi Dominum, et hæc dixit mihi.

verses.textEn: Then, when it was late on the same day, on the first of the Sabbaths, and the doors were closed where the disciples were gathered, for fear of the Jews, Jesus came and stood in their midst, and he said to them: “Peace to you.”
verses.textLa: Cum ergo sero esset die illo, una Sabbatorum, et fores essent clausæ, ubi erant discipuli congregati propter metum Iudæorum: venit Iesus, et stetit in medio, et dixit eis: Pax vobis.

verses.textEn: And when he had said this, he showed them his hands and side. And the disciples were gladdened when they saw the Lord.
verses.textLa: Et cum hoc dixisset, ostendit eis manus, et latus. Gavisi sunt ergo discipuli, viso Domino.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he said to them again: “Peace to you. As the Father has sent me, so I send you.”
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo eis iterum: Pax vobis. Sicut misit me Pater, et ego mitto vos.

verses.textEn: When he had said this, he breathed on them. And he said to them: “Receive the Holy Spirit.
verses.textLa: Hæc cum dixisset, insufflavit: et dixit eis: Accipite Spiritum Sanctum:

verses.textEn: Those whose sins you shall forgive, they are forgiven them, and those whose sins you shall retain, they are retained.”
verses.textLa: quorum remiseritis peccata, remittuntur eis: et quorum retinueritis, retenta sunt.

verses.textEn: Now Thomas, one of the twelve, who is called the Twin, was not with them when Jesus arrived.
verses.textLa: Thomas autem unus ex duodecim, qui dicitur Didymus, non erat cum eis quando venit Iesus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the other disciples said to him, “We have seen the Lord.” But he said to them, “Unless I will see in his hands the mark of the nails and place my finger into the place of the nails, and place my hand into his side, I will not believe.”
verses.textLa: Dixerunt ergo ei alii discipuli: Vidimus Dominum. Ille autem dixit eis: Nisi videro in manibus eius fixuram clavorum, et mittam digitum meum in locum clavorum, et mittam manum meam in latus eius, non credam.

verses.textEn: And after eight days, again his disciples were within, and Thomas was with them. Jesus arrived, though the doors had been closed, and he stood in their midst and said, “Peace to you.”
verses.textLa: Et post dies octo, iterum erant discipuli eius intus: et Thomas cum eis. Venit Iesus ianuis clausis, et stetit in medio, et dixit: Pax vobis.

verses.textEn: Next, he said to Thomas: “Look at my hands, and place your finger here; and bring your hand close, and place it at my side. And do not choose to be unbelieving, but faithful.”
verses.textLa: Deinde dicit Thomæ: Infer digitum tuum huc, et vide manus meas, et affer manum tuam, et mitte in latus meum: et noli esse incredulus, sed fidelis.

verses.textEn: Thomas responded and said to him, “My Lord and my God.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Thomas, et dixit ei: Dominus meus, et Deus meus.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to him: “You have seen me, Thomas, so you have believed. Blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed.”
verses.textLa: Dixit ei Iesus: Quia vidisti me Thoma, credidisti: beati qui non viderunt, et crediderunt.

verses.textEn: Jesus also accomplished many other signs in the sight of his disciples. These have not been written in this book.
verses.textLa: Multa quidem, et alia signa fecit Iesus in conspectu discipulorum suorum, quæ non sunt scripta in libro hoc.

verses.textEn: But these things have been written, so that you may believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God, and so that, in believing, you may have life in his name.
verses.textLa: Hæc autem scripta sunt ut credatis, quia Iesus est Christus Filius Dei: et ut credentes, vitam habeatis in nomine eius.

verses.textEn: After this, Jesus manifested himself again to the disciples at the Sea of Tiberias. And he manifested himself in this way.
verses.textLa: Postea manifestavit se iterum Iesus discipulis ad mare Tiberiadis. Manifestavit autem sic:

verses.textEn: These were together: Simon Peter and Thomas, who is called the Twin, and Nathanael, who was from Cana of Galilee, and the sons of Zebedee, and two others of his disciples.
verses.textLa: Erant simul Simon Petrus, et Thomas, qui dicitur Didymus, et Nathanael, qui erat a Cana Galilææ, et filii Zebedæi, et alii ex discipulis eius duo.

verses.textEn: Simon Peter said to them, “I am going fishing.” They said to him, “And we are going with you.” And they went and climbed into the ship. And in that night, they caught nothing.
verses.textLa: Dicit eis Simon Petrus: Vado piscari. Dicunt ei: Venimus et nos tecum. Et exierunt, et ascenderunt in navim: et illa nocte nihil prendiderunt.

verses.textEn: But when morning arrived, Jesus stood on the shore. Yet the disciples did not realize that it was Jesus.
verses.textLa: Mane autem facto stetit Iesus in littore: non tamen cognoverunt discipuli quia Iesus est.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus said to them, “Children, do you have any food?” They answered him, “No.”
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo eis Iesus: Pueri numquid pulmentarium habetis? Responderunt ei: Non.

verses.textEn: He said to them, “Cast the net to the right side of the ship, and you will find some.” Therefore, they cast it out, and then they were not able to draw it in, because of the multitude of fish.
verses.textLa: Dicit eis: Mittite in dexteram navigii rete: et invenietis. Miserunt ergo: et iam non valebant illud trahere præ multitudine piscium.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the disciple whom Jesus loved said to Peter, “It is the Lord.” Simon Peter, when he had heard that it was the Lord, wrapped his tunic around himself, (for he was naked) and he cast himself into the sea.
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo discipulus ille, quem diligebat Iesus, Petro: Dominus est. Simon Petrus cum audisset quia Dominus est, tunica succinxit se (erat enim nudus) et misit se in mare.

verses.textEn: Then the other disciples arrived in a boat, (for they were not far from the land, only about two hundred cubits) dragging the net with the fish.
verses.textLa: Alii autem discipuli navigio venerunt: (non enim longe erant a terra, sed quasi cubitis ducentis) trahentes rete piscium.

verses.textEn: Then, when they climbed down to the land they saw burning coals prepared, and fish already placed above them, and bread.
verses.textLa: Ut ergo descenderunt in terram, viderunt prunas positas, et piscem superpositum, et panem.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to them, “Bring some of the fish that you have just now caught.”
verses.textLa: Dicit eis Iesus: Afferte de piscibus, quos prendidistis nunc.

verses.textEn: Simon Peter climbed up and drew in the net to land: full of large fish, one hundred and fifty-three of them. And although there were so many, the net was not torn.
verses.textLa: Ascendit Simon Petrus, et traxit rete in terram, plenum magnis piscibus centum quinquaginta tribus. Et cum tanti essent, non est scissum rete.
verses.notes: The catch of fish represents souls saved by the Church in the end times. The size of the fish represents the number of souls saved: a large number. The number of the fish represents the way that they are saved: through the holy Rosary, represented figuratively by the 153 Hail Mary’s found in the traditional form of the prayer.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to them, “Approach and dine.” And not one of them sitting down to eat dared to ask him, “Who are you?” For they knew that it was the Lord.
verses.textLa: Dicit eis Iesus: Venite, prandete. Et nemo audebat discumbentium interrogare eum: Tu quis es? scientes, quia Dominus est.

verses.textEn: And Jesus approached, and he took bread, and he gave it to them, and similarly with the fish.
verses.textLa: Et venit Iesus, et accipit panem, et dat eis, et piscem similiter.

verses.textEn: This was now the third time that Jesus was manifested to his disciples, after he had resurrected from the dead.
verses.textLa: Hoc iam tertio manifestatus est Iesus discipulis suis cum resurrexisset a mortuis.
verses.notes: Notice that the verb tense is active not passive. Jesus has the power, as the Son of God, to raise himself up from the dead. At the general resurrection, we shall all be resurrected from the dead (passive tense) by Christ. But at His own resurrection, Christ resurrected himself from the dead (active tense).

verses.textEn: Then, when they had dined, Jesus said to Simon Peter, “Simon, son of John, do you love me more than these?” He said to him, “Yes, Lord, you know that I love you.” He said to him, “Feed my lambs.”
verses.textLa: Cum ergo prandissent, dicit Simoni Petro Iesus: Simon Ioannis diligis me plus his? Dicit ei: Etiam Domine, tu scis quia amo te. Dicit ei: Pasce agnos meos.

verses.textEn: He said to him again: “Simon, son of John, do you love me?” He said to him, “Yes, Lord, you know that I love you.” He said to him, “Feed my lambs.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei iterum: Simon Ioannis, diligis me? Ait illi: Etiam Domine, tu scis quia amo te. Dicit ei: Pasce agnos meos.

verses.textEn: He said to him a third time, “Simon, son of John, do you love me?” Peter was very grieved that he had asked him a third time, “Do you love me?” And so he said to him: “Lord, you know all things. You know that I love you.” He said to him, “Feed my sheep.
verses.textLa: Dicit ei tertio: Simon Ioannis, amas me? Contristatus est Petrus, quia dixit ei tertio, Amas me? et dixit ei: Domine tu omnia nosti: tu scis quia amo te. Dixit ei: Pasce oves meas.

verses.textEn: Amen, amen, I say to you, when you were younger, you girded yourself and walked wherever you wanted. But when you are older, you will extend your hands, and another shall gird you and lead you where you do not want to go.”
verses.textLa: Amen, amen dico tibi: cum esses iunior cingebas te, et ambulabas ubi volebas: cum autem senueris, extendes manus tuas, et alius te cinget, et ducet quo tu non vis.

verses.textEn: Now he said this to signify by what kind of death he would glorify God. And when he had said this, he said to him, “Follow me.”
verses.textLa: Hoc autem dixit significans qua morte clarificaturus esset Deum. Et cum hoc dixisset, dicit ei: Sequere me.

verses.textEn: Peter, turning around, saw the disciple whom Jesus loved following, the one who also had leaned on his chest at supper and said, “Lord, who is it who shall betray you?”
verses.textLa: Conversus Petrus vidit illum discipulum, quem diligebat Iesus, sequentem, qui et recubuit in cœna super pectus eius, et dixit: Domine quis est qui tradet te?

verses.textEn: Therefore, when Peter had seen him, he said to Jesus, “Lord, but what about this one?”
verses.textLa: Hunc ergo cum vidisset Petrus, dixit Iesu: Domine hic autem quid?

verses.textEn: Jesus said to him: “If I want him to remain until I return, what is that to you? You follow me.”
verses.textLa: Dicit ei Iesus: Sic eum volo manere donec veniam, quid ad te? Tu me sequere.
verses.notes: All the Apostles were martyred except John. This is a foreshadowing of the last days before the Return of Christ, when almost the whole Church will suffer severe persecution, but one part will be spared, so that the Church will not pass away prior to Christ’s return.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the saying went out among the brothers that this disciple would not die. But Jesus did not say to him that he would not die, but only, “If I want him to remain until I return, what is that to you?”
verses.textLa: Exiit ergo sermo iste inter fratres quia discipulus ille non moritur. Et non dixit ei Iesus: Non moritur: sed: Sic eum volo manere donec veniam, quid ad te?

verses.textEn: This is the same disciple who offers testimony about these things, and who has written these things. And we know that his testimony is true.
verses.textLa: Hic est discipulus ille, qui testimonium perhibet de his, et scripsit hæc: et scimus, quia verum est testimonium eius.

verses.textEn: Now there are also many other things that Jesus did, which, if each of these were written down, the world itself, I suppose, would not be able to contain the books that would be written.
verses.textLa: Sunt autem et alia multa, quæ fecit Iesus: quæ si scribantur per singula, nec ipsum arbitror mundum capere posse eos, qui scribendi sunt, libros.
